item.title: Welcome!
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded:
Hello and Welcome to College Outside!
This blog is a brainchild born from many hours of discussion on the trail, and I decided that it's time to put my plan into action.
As a college student, I get all of my know-how from my friends, or from learning from my mistakes. But for many things in the outdoors, mistakes can have a big cost. I wanted to create a place where the student community can come together and share stories, tips, and information on how to successfully be an outdoorsman while in school. Some posts will be directed at city kids who think that Keds are ok hiking footwear, others at more experienced students who want to give and share tips.
So what makes College Outside different from every other gear/trip/outdoor junkie website? Essentially it comes down to this: there is a difference between being a mountaineer and a mountaineer in college, a hiker and a weekend college hiker, a climber and going to the local gym once a week. There are plenty of movies, articles, and blogs out there for the average outdoorsman, and although college students may follow this advice (as I do), the average student can't afford $450 mountaineering boots for their first winter hike. This is an attempt to decode the outdoor world for the average, broke-ass, college student in a way that makes the outdoors safer and more accesible that ever before.
For now, I will be writing all of the posts, from gear reviews to workout and food tips, trip descriptions and awesome-people profiles. I'll also try to address many of the things that may be too awkward to talk about (pooping on the trail, smoke screens, smoke tents, forgetting TP, etc.) In the near future however, some of my future outdoors men and women will be guest posting to share more info than my Hawaii-goes-to-New Hampshire self can.
In the mean time, enjoy, share, ask questions! If you have anything you're curious about, or would like to know more about, please email me or leave a comment and I'll dedicate a whole post to it.
Go outside!
Sarah

item.title: Guide to Cheap Gear
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: Ok let's be real. I procrastinate by reading Outside Magazine's Best Gear of the Year and get more excited when I receive the monthly Patagonia magazine than a 15 year old girl does when she receives a Cosmo. But most of it is fantasy. I have a pinterest board with more gear on it than I could ever use, and am constantly on the look out for great deals, since most of my gear fondling stops before my debit card comes out. There are a few things that are necessary when attaining gear at a fraction of the cost: patience, persistance, and an ungodly willingness to wake up at 4am. Tip Number #1: The REI Used Gear Sale. They happen four times a year, and if you weren't an REI member before, these four events make it worth it. Essentially, they are a time for REI to re-sell all the gear and clothing that has been returned at a fraction of the price. Most things will be tagged as "broken" or "used", but most items are either brand new, used once, or totally fixable. The down side? Although the store will open up at 10am, the line usually starts forming around 5am. So go to sleep early, bring a warm sleeping bag, some friends, and a plan. I've scored an Osprey Aura 50 liters for $50, a down jacket with a small hole that patched with ShoeGoo (waterproof and bombproof), trekking poles, etc. You get the point. Tip #2: TheClymb.com. A fantastic site with discounted gear whose velvet rope needs only an email to get through. They have daily and weekly deals and will email you as soon as a new one comes out. Tip #3: ODAT Tracker. Any respectable gear junkie already has steapandcheap.com as their home page, but ODAT tracker is a free app you can download from the itunes app store that is 10x better. It follows backcountry.com's one deal at a time sites (ODAT sites) as well as the daily deals from many other companies. Perfect for those of us with gear ADD. Happy Shopping! S

item.title: What to Wear: Winter Hiking
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: Winter hiking involves a bit more preparation than your average summer hike. A water bottle and PB&J won't cut it, principally for safety reasons. I'm going to go through the layers that I would wear as well as the things I would bring with me on an average winter day hike. (The brands are of course interchangeable, and everyone finds a system that works for them, but these are the basics.) *For a bottom and top baselayer, I usually wear Under Armour Cold-Gear. They are synthetic, sweat wicking layers that will dry quickly, but more importantly, keep you warm even when they get wet. Any sort of synthetic (not cotton) base layer will work. *Over the base layers, I put on water/wind proof pants. You don't really need to buy anything new, your snowboarding/ski/rain pants will do just fine. [caption id="attachment_55" align="alignright" width="130" caption="Patagonia R1"][/caption] *Up top I put on a micro fleece (my personal favorite is the Patagonia R1)  and then a down or synthetic filled jacket, followed by either a hard or soft shell (like your rain jacket). The shell is important to keep the wind/snow out. Ten minutes into your hike, you'll be so warm you'llprobably strip down to your base layer and fleece. A down jacket can be replaced by many layers of fleece for smaller day hikes, although a down is lighter and packs down smaller in your bag.   *Wool socks are crucial to keep your feet warm, again no cotton, and of course a hat and gloves. *Microspikes, snowshoes, crampons, or any type of traction for your feet is crucial. It will allow you to conquer any ice on the trail that would otherwise turn you away. [caption id="attachment_57" align="alignright" width="144" caption="Microspikes, they run about $60, $50 with a 20% off student discount at EMS"][/caption] *Gators are a good thing to have if you can get a good deal on them. They keep the snow out of your boots and your feet dry in snow. They also keep your crampons from catching your pants and ripping a huge hole in them. In your pack, you should have: -Extra socks -Plenty of water (put an extra sock around your Nalgenes to keep it from freezing). -Twice the amount of food that you normally would. Your body burns way more calories in the winter trying to keep warm as it does in the summer. -A first aid kit of course! You can pick up a basic kit at EMS or REI for under $15. In a crunch, an ace bandage and a bottle of ibuprofen will do. -A headlamp, map, compass, and of course, some chocolate. Patagonia has some great technical systems on their website to give you some more ideas, but most things can be replaced with less expensive versions. Questions?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Remember that if you use a camelback to blow the water back through the tube into the bladder because the tube will freeze EVEN IF IT'S "INSULATED". An alternative to this that works great is taking one of the camelbacks that you can use as a backpack (shoulder and chest straps), wear it backwards under your jacket (i.e. on your chest outside of a few base layers) and then run the tube down your arm and secure it to your wrist with an elastic, hair tie, or watch and then put your jacket on over the top. With this system it keeps your bladder from freezing and when you're thirsty you just drink from your wrist, pretty ninja. I stole this tactic from a Navy Seal and it worked like a charm for last winter's ascent of Mt. Katahdin in Maine, I've been using it ever since.

Sounds like a great idea, as long as it doesn't leak! But yes, camelbacks can be a pain in the winter since the tubes and mouthpieces freeze so fast. An insulated bladder keeps the main body from freezing as fast, but I like the idea of using your body heat to keep it warm.

item.title: The Ultimate PB&J
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: There are only so many Peanut Butter and Jelly sandwiches you can eat in your life time, before you start dreaming peanut butter flavored dreams. I, personally, can not eat them outside of an outdoors-y setting, but they are still my go-to when hiking/climbing/snowboarding etc. The jelly has a quick sugar boost, and the bread and protein from the peanut butter keep me going all day long. However, after hundreds and hundreds of PB&J's, I finally started to get creative, and with the help of some friends, we came up with some winning combinations: 1) PB&J not fill you up enough? ADD MORE PEANUT BUTTER. Both sides, as much as you dare. Warning: This may happen to you ----> [caption id="attachment_80" align="alignright" width="300" caption="It all ends up in the same place, right?"][/caption] 2) The Class PB&J + cereal. This is similar to a turkey sandwich with chips. It adds crunch and flavor. My favorites including adding Peanut Butter Captain Crunch, honey nut cheerios, and coco-puffs, but any cereal will do. Warning: the cereal will get soggy after a couple of hours, so plan on this being your first snack and/or breakfast. 3) Try adding any sort of instant drink to it: hot coco, instant coffee, Tang, or open up a tea bag if you're desperate. These will give you an extra sugar or caffeine burst, as well as taste delicious. In any case, make sure to put peanut butter on both sides of the bread, and then add the jelly, it will keep it from getting soggy and from the jelly going everywhere. Any other suggestions? -S

item.title: My First (Free) Triathlon
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: Last summer was my first summer spent in Boston. I had a full time job in the city and so in order to keep myself sane, I became a true weekend warrior. For 10 weeks, I did not spend one weekend in Boston. Most weekends were spent in New Hampshire or Maine hiking or climbing, but one weekend was spent on Cape Code for my first sprint triathlon. I had been convinced to sign up for this race six months before hand; July 17thseemed so far away. I liked the idea of having something legit to train for. I was already a decent swimmer, would run 5 miles if I had to, and biking’s not that hard, right? [caption id="attachment_114" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Triathletes...or something"][/caption] The downside? It would cost me around $85 to sign up. There was no way in hell that I was going to pay that much to exercise. I feel that this is a common theme with a lot of the cool races I want to do: they’re just too expensive. However, whether it’s a Spartan Race, Snowshoe race, or triathlon, there is always a way to get a discount or to get away with doing them for free! This is my account of my first sprint triathlon, which I got away with being legitimately registered without paying a dime. [caption id="attachment_113" align="alignright" width="179" caption="Handing out t-shirts before the race."][/caption] As all races go, there are early bird specials, and last minute registration penalties, and of course I waited until the last minute to sign up. The four people I was going to do it with were already registered, but by the time I tried to sign up, the race was already full! Desperate, I emailed and called the race organizers, with pleas of “but I’m a student and this is my first tri!” and “but all my friends are already signed up!” These pathetic attempts did not of course work, but in this case, persistence paid off. The race organizer told me that if I volunteered to help with packet handout and registration the day before, I could have a spot in the race. The bonus? Volunteers race for free. WIN! I spent the day before the race on the beach, handing out t-shirts and packets and getting to see all of my competition. Race day was fantastic. It was an open water swim, AKA my forte (I can’t say the same for a couple of my friends who probably would have drowned without their wetsuits), scenic bike loop over gently rolling terrain, and flat gorgeous 5k run along the beach’s bike path. There are definitely expensive parts to a triathlon aside from the registration fee: principally the gear. However, being my first tri, and with no pressure to win, I didn’t care if I had the top of the line, or even proper gear. Being from Hawaii, I pride myself on being able to swim in any conditions, with no aid. Therefore, while everyone else wore a wetsuit, I wore a bikini top and pink tri-shorts that I had bought on TheClymb. I wore my running shoes to bike in which helped speed up my second transition, although probably cost me some time on the bike. Also, my piece of crap 1980’s road bike that I had bought from a friend literally fell apart in the middle of the race. The seat basically exploded, which I somehow managed to put back together with some Allen wrenches, despite my shaking, endorphin filled hands. Yet despite this disaster, I had the time of my life. Sure I didn’t finish in any sort of standing, and I didn’t have the best or newest gear, but hey, I’m now a Triathlete right? Summary: Consider volunteering to get free entry, and borrowing/renting gear instead of buying gear to make race day financially painless! item.title: Black Diamond Embers Review
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded:
How Not Buying Fancy Gear Can Save More Money Then You Ever Imagined I started telemarking when all my friends thought getting down the bunny hill without falling meant you were good at snowboarding. I needed something to keep me interested, and hey, who doesn’t like being at the bottom of the learning curve. It is also a handy skill to have when you go on your annual family ski vacation and there is absolutely no snow and you can’t face one more round of bridge with the grandfather. Oh yeah, and its pretty rad in the backcountry. The snow was so unbelievably nonexistent that my mom and I didn’t bring our skis with us and we decided we would rent if and when we hit the slopes. So day one of the ski trip, we ducked into Alpenglow sports in Tahoe City, and picked up matching pairs of Black Diamond Embers. Cost to Rent: With boots and poles, $49/day, $27/day for just the skies Cost to buy them? $589, no bindings. (Check out http://www.evo.com, http://galacticsnowsports.com, or http://www.levelninesports.com for online deals.) What BD says: The all-new Black Diamond Ember is designed from the ground up for women who want an everyday, all-mountain ski for frontside terrain. Its 3D Sandwich construction offers up precision turns on firm snow, plus a light and lively feel thanks to its poplar wood core. A deep sidecut and wide, soft flexing tip make for an easy-turning ski ideal for any day short of a full-on powder fest.
  • 95 mm waist, full-length camber, and women's-specific flex for lively, snappy feel out of every turn
  • Traditional tip and tail rise offer full-length edge contact and maximum stability
  • More sidecut, lighter and easier turning at any speed than the Verdict
  • 3D Sandwich poplar wood core with ABS tapered sidewalls for maximum energy return
  • Dual Torsion Bow Technology with two ribs puts power to the edges from tip to tail
Optimal use: 40% soft snow / 60% hard snow What I, (MD 20/20) say: As the surfer-cum-ski bum adjusted my bindings, he dropped the casual “these are pretty skinny for Squaw, but you should be fine because there isn’t much snow”. The Embers are 95 mm underfoot. Compared to the 71 m waist on the Karhu Outbounds I usually tele on, these were freakin’ water skis. That aside, I decided to give them a go. At 7 lbs 8 oz, you could find lighter skis, or you could find heavier, but for my walk from the car to the lift line, I barely noticed them on my shoulder. Nothing dramatic about putting them on, other than the usual struggle of finding my way around a new binding system (TwentyTwo Designs Axle’s, for those of you who are interested. They get a thumbs up). Once on the snow (all 12” of it), the skis were great. Too great. I could be way off balance, throw my hip into the hill, not buckle the waist belt of my pack and the massive side cut still bite into the slope. It was awesome. I am not the world’s greatest telemarker, but I was carving turns and implementing the hop like it was nobody’s business. And when I got lazy, the skis almost begged me to make an alpine turn. The tips on these babies are so soft, they coax you into keeping you weight forward, which is great, if your heels are attached. I felt as though I had to work to keep my weight centered enough to drop a knee, but this was mostly masked by the ease with which the Embers turned. [caption id="attachment_98" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Squaw Valley is Beautiful. 0" of snow is not."][/caption] The bottom line: You can probably find something cheaper that will make you a better skier at your neighborhood ski swap (save on gear and lessons!). They are great on hard pack, but I feel like they might act a bit hung-over (read: “sluggish and unresponsive”) in serious powpow. If you want a ski that will let you mess up and still make it through the turn standing and if you were to primarily telemark inbounds on hardpack/corduroy and/or are new to the sport of telemarking, these skis are for you. That being said, if you are looking to get into telemarking, or go to school near some big resorts, AND you can pick up a used/discounted pair, you and the Embers will have a rowdy time. BUT...I would skimp on the skis and splurge on the boots. However, you can find your self a good, safe tele set up minus boots for about $200-$300 online or at your local ski shop. M.Carey AKA Mad Dawg, New Mexico, Tufts 2014 Editor’s note: Considering renting the skis first, and then if you fall in love, most ski shops will sell you those rental skis and a much discounted price.

item.title: Adventure Books for Christmas Break
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: Christmas vacation is always a well needed break from a heavy semester. It's a time to sleep in, eat some good home cooking, ski your face off, and of course, read some great books that will whet your appetite for future adventures. Here are a few of my favorites: On the Ridge Between Life and Death by David Roberts What compels mountain climbers to take the risks that they do? Is it the thrill in the physical accomplishment, in managing to defy the odds, or both — and why do they continue to do what they do in the face of such great danger? In On the Ridge Between Life and Death, David Roberts confronts these questions head-on as he recounts the exhilarating highs and desperate lows of his climbing career. By the time he was twenty-two, Roberts had already been involved in three fatal mountain climbing accidents and had escaped death himself by the sheerest of luck. And yet, as he acknowledges, few things have brought him more joy than climbing. In a world before Gortex, cams, and Freedom of the Hills, there were mountaineers and adventurers who pushed the limits in some of the harshest and most remote conditions on the planet. David Roberts is certainly one of those individuals. This book is a must read for any aspiring, intermediate, or seasoned hiker/climber/mountaineer. (Side note: Roberts was a mentor to Krakauer, very cool.) This book was given to me by someone who taught me to respect climbing for the dangerous and beautiful sport that it is. Into Thin Air By Jon Krakauer Into Thin Air is a personal account of the disaster that occurred near the summit of Everest in May of 1996, when five expeditioners perished in a massive Everest scale storm. Initially, Krakauer, a journalist for adventure magazine Outside, stated that his intentions to climb Everest were purely professional. The original magazine story was to have Krakauer climb only to base camp, and report on the commercialization of the mountain. However, the idea of Everest reawakened his childhood desire for climbing the mountain. Krakauer asked his editor to put off the story for a year so that he could train for a climb to the summit. From there, the book chronologically moves between events that take place on the mountain and the unfolding tragedy which takes place during the push to the summit. Krakauer takes his us inside both the drive and the disaster that accompanies climbing Mount Everest. But he also takes us within himself as he relates not only his physical experiences on Everest, but his emotional experiences and the toll the 1996 disaster had on his life. You will truly be immersed in his harsh Himalayan lifestyle. Swimming with Crocodiles by Will Chaffey Will Chaffey was 18 when he boarded a plane in New York bound for Australia. He had no acceptance letters from colleges and no plan. Will soon meets an enigmatic wanderer and herpetologist named Geoff there and with him crossed the inland desert to the tropical northwest coast, home to the saltwater crocodile, a predator surviving from the age of dinosaurs and a known man-eater. Together they devised a plan to explore the remote Prince Regent River, a trek so dangerous it had never been attempted by white men. Passing through harsh, primeval country, shadowed by Aborigines, and physically worn down, they find themselves locked in a life-and-death struggle when their food runs out and, unable to leave, they are stalked by a hungry crocodile. Swimming with Crocodiles is both a riveting adventure and a wry meditation on the journey to adulthood. Beautifully written, it brims with curiosity and wonder at the natural world, with a nice balance between appreciation of the Australian outback, and a healthy fear of it’s dangers. If you haven't yet been down under, this will surely put Australian on your list of go-to places. Into the Wild by Jon Krakauer In April 1992 a young man from a well-to-do family hitchhiked to Alaska and walked alone into the wilderness north of Mt. McKinley. His name was Christopher Johnson McCandless. He had given $25,000 in savings to charity, abandoned his car and most of his possessions, burned all the cash in his wallet, and invented a new life for himself.Four months later, his decomposed body was found by a moose hunter… For those of you who have seen the movie or even if you haven't, reading this book is a must. Not only is it more precise account, but it gives an in depth look into the boy known as Alexander Supertramp’s hopes, desires, and motives. To me, he represents the wanderer in all of us that seeks to find meaning in life.   Happy New Year everyone! Hope 2012 is as crazy as 2011 was. It has some big shoes to fill!

item.title: OuRAY!
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_126" align="aligncenter" width="203" caption="Sweet heel hook when the bottom of the ice broke off."][/caption] About this time last year, I spent my first winter break in Durango, Colorado, home to every sport imaginable and the most unstable snowpack in the country. Durango is a small town located in Southwest Colorado, a 7-hour drive from Denver, but most notably, a 1.5 hour drive along the Million Dollar Highway to Ouray (in the summer that is). [caption id="attachment_124" align="alignright" width="225" caption="Gorgeous view, terrifying drive"][/caption] Ouray is home to the world-famous Ouray Ice Park where they hold a 3-day Ice Festival every year. Due to bad timing, I won’t be able to make it this year, but since today is the first day of the festival and competition, I was feeling nostalgic. I had heard about it last year, but there was no way in hell I was going to drive the 70 miles, along narrow winding roads, in one of the coldest winters Durango has every had. They call it the Million Dollar Highway for its breathtaking views of the Rockies, its canyons and peaks, made especially brilliant as a frozen winter wonderland. The view is particularly good on the road’s most precarious parts due to a steep cliff on one side and no railing on the other side, with a drop off that makes you pray that no one will be driving in the opposite direction. I’m uncomfortable even driving down my driveway if it is the least bit icy, and so I went in search of a ride. I spent a few hours in Backcountry Experience, one of the local gear junkie stores in town, trying on ice climbing boots that were way out of my price range, and eventually started talking to the guys that worked there about the festival. I casually mentioned that I was looking for a ride up, and although they themselves weren’t going, they had a friend that was. Long story short, I ended up standing on a random girl’s doorstep at 4:30 am, with the mantra DIFTS (do it for the story) running through my head. Turns out that the four people I was heading up with were Fort Lewis College seniors or recent graduates who were nasty backcountry skiers, and novice ice climbers like myself.  The drive ended up taking us 4 hours in horrid conditions, but once we got there it was worth it. [caption id="attachment_125" align="alignleft" width="225" caption="A view of the ice canyon, with the sponsor's tents up above."][/caption] All I had brought with me was a harness and my helmet, but every major ice climbing brand from Scarpa to La Sportiva to Black Diamond was there, and I was soon demoing (for free) those super fly, light green, La Sportiva Nepal EVOs that I had been trying on the day before. (They were magic by the way. Maybe one day I’ll deserve them.) In addition, Black Diamond hooked me up with a pair of shiny crampons and ice tools, and Patagonia let me demo a sexy red hard shell that fit perfectly over my helmet and down jacket. Once we were all geared up, we made our way down into the ice canyon of my dreams. I had never seen so much perfect ice in my life. Some of it was man made, but all in all, it was the ultimate ice playground. There were top-ropes set up everywhere and soon we hooked up with a group that was more than willing to let us climb with them. This was only my second or third time ice climbing ever, but the people there were extremely supportive, ready to teach, and more importantly, ready to party. Once the festival ends, Ouray turns into a massive celebration of outdoorsmen, novice and professional, who are just pumped for another excellent ice season.   [caption id="attachment_127" align="alignleft" width="225" caption="Having a go at it."][/caption] Festivals like this one are an excellent opportunity for ice climbers of all experience levels to try out the sport and really get to know what it’s about. With all the free gear you could ask for to demo, what’s not to love?

item.title: weekend warrior
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: I used to feel that my love of the outdoors was like a fleeting romance, a four year fling that I would have to painfully push aside as I entered the "real' world. I experienced a taste of this lack luster breakup last summer when I worked a 40-hour a week internship in downtown Boston. Sure, I left to go up North every single weekend that summer, but I found myself daydreaming of my next weekend trip, and making packing lists on monday afternoon. If you're one of the lucky few who has found a paying job in the outdoor industry during the summer, we envy you. But if you're like many students who are pressured to put their summer camp days to rest to work for a more traditional 9-5, there are ways to keep your outside spirit kindled. The key is to become a weekend warrior. Make every weekend count! Make sure you start scheduling events and trips even before your break starts. That way, you'll never waste a weekend.

item.dc:creator: sokodavid
item.content:encoded: This past summer I had the incredible opportunity to travel to Alaska and sea kayak for 2.5 weeks in Prince William Sound.  It was an great chance to learn how to paddle, navigate, and how to camp on a beach.  However, there was one skill we did not have time to learn... rolling a kayak.  I had seen it done, but didnt have the chance to give it a try.  So, when I got home I sat in front of my computer and watched a few hours of youtube instructional videos.  Then I took my family's kayak 20 feet off the shore in Wellfleet harbor and rolled over.  It took a few days, but finally, somehow, I was able to complete the flip.  Hopefully this is not a skill you will need to use when sea kayak - if the waves are that big, get out of the water.  However, for those of you looking to do some white water kayaking its definitely a skill you are going to want (unless you like swimming in rapids). Ive attached some videos to this post so you can see what it looks like to fail.  As one could imagine, sitting upside down in a boat is not the most comfortable experience.  My recommendation to you is to get used to it - the more comfortable you are hanging out in the water the easier it will be for you to learn how to roll.  Hopefully these videos will get you interested and will inspire you to go on youtube and watch the pros at work!  So check out these videos (these are without paddles - but you will get the point) - one of them is of me failing, while the other one is a success.  My recommendation to you is to grab a friend, grab some boats, bring a camera (its good to see how you mess up / its pretty funny) and jump in the water. item.title: A Spartan Sprint Recap: When 5 Miles Takes 2 Hours
item.dc:creator: SummerRepublic
item.content:encoded: Pennsylvania Spartan Sprint—July 14, 2012 As I walked in, I saw participants heading home, walking tenderly and covered in mud. The race director said this was the hardest, longest race in their “sprint” category. I was also literally facing a ski mountain. I began to feel I had underestimated this race. Five miles is nothing to a half-marathoner, right? Quick, easy, painless? Wrong. The race started with a run straight up the mountain, which eventually got so steep running was just inefficient. The first few obstacles were okay, walls and rope climbs; then we had to carry a bucket of gravel up and down a hill—that was almost impossible for me. I made it, but slowly. There were a few obstacles I simply could not do due to lack of arm strength or (truly) because I was too short. I quickly learned that in Spartan races, if you can’t complete the obstacle, you have to drop and do 30 burpees (I did 90 total—3 sets). (For a list of all the obstacles, check out the website—spartanrace.com). There was a lot of carrying heavy things up and down hills, crawling under barbed wire, scaling walls, and water obstacles. And lots and lots of mud. But through it all, I found myself running when I could and just pushing on with a very raw sense of focus and determination. A really pleasant surprise for me was the camaraderie that was felt along every aspect of the race. If you passed someone, they shouted a “Good job!” or “Good luck!” to you, and you responded with the same encouragement. I wouldn’t have gotten through some of the obstacles without the help of others. I thank the (cute) guys who gave me a lift over some of the walls that were almost twice my height, the girl who held down the rope wall as I scaled it, and one of the ladies who gave me a tip for one of the obstacles. Grateful and inspired by their help, I tried to return the same tips and aid to other runners.The race ended with an incredibly satisfying leap over fire, a t-shirt, medal, showers, and a banana. All runners were chip-timed and results were posted up within minutes. I couldn't believe the clock; five miles of obstacles and mountainous terrain took me 2 hours. But I still placed first in my age group and 366 overall. Woah. If I had one criticism of the race, it would be that on some of the downhill and uphill parts of the trail, the terrain truly was a little treacherous, with loose gravel and rocks, or very slippery grass. It worried me that the course posed such a risk for a twisted ankle, but I guess that’s why they have you sign the waiver clearly stating that you may die. Overall, the Spartan Race was a pleasure to run, as masochistic as it may be. The atmosphere was lively, there was a real “Spartan warrior” spirit among the racers, and the course and obstacles were cool as hell. The pain was worth it. I am a Spartan.

item.dc:creator: chloerotman
item.content:encoded:
And just so you get an even better idea, I’ll tell you a little bit about what I bought! Harness: This was a harness I had borrowed from a friend this winter.It is a simple design with easy to adjust straps. I chose it because it has hard gear loops that can hold both rock and ice gear well and it has lots of them in both the front and back of the harness. As for sizing, I bought it slightly bigger than I would normally fit so that even though there is a little extra room during the warmer seasons, in the winter, snow pants will fit more easily. This is something you should consider if you think youll be doing ice climbing in addition to rock.
Black Diamond Primrose Women's Harness $55 (full price)
Shoes:  I bought this pair of shoes for comfort. Since I am only a beginner climber, stiffness wasnt a big factor for me. I wanted something I could bear to stand in for 10 mins so I wouldnt have to take my shoes off too often while belaying between pitches( on multi-pitch climbs). I chose laces because I like having more ability to adjust tightness in different parts of the shoe since I have wide feet but velcro would be faster getting in and out so that is up to your personal preference. This specific pair are not especially sticky so if you plan on doing a lot of slab climbing, I would consider finding a stickier shoe. However, it is great for everything else so far. The final factor I considered ( only because I had tried another friend’s shoe and made this discovery) is the thickness of the toe. This becomes important when crack climbing. Personally, I wanted a stiff but slimmer (slimmer top to bottom, not side to side) toe because other shoes I had tried had trouble jamming into cracks with the thicker toe-ed shoe.
Evolv-Defy-Lace-Climbing-Shoe $80 (full price)
Helmet:  This choice was pretty easy since there are only a few helmet options out there. I chose to go with the Elia because of its pony tail hole but unless the helmet happens to be the same price or not more expensive than the other helmet options, I would go with the standard option since the pony tail hole isnt even that much higher than you would have it in the normal helmet. This of course something you only need to consider as a girl...
Petzl Elia Women's Helmet $65 (full price)
ATC:  This ATC is slightly lighter weight because, as you’ll notice, there is a hole in the center. This isnt super important but may be nice as you get further into the sport and are concerned about how much weight you are carrying.
Black Diamond ATC Belay Device ($29 full price)
Locking Carabiner: You'll need this to lock in the ATC and rope.
Black Diamond Rocklock Screwgate Carabiner $10(full price)
Chalk bag:Get a cheap one. There isnt anything special about these. My only criteria was matching!
Black Diamond Chalk Bag $22 (full price)
These are the basics. As you will soon discover, the rabbit hole goes much deeper with all this gear but here is a good place to start. Happy climbing!

item.title: Baby's First Multi Pitch Climb
item.dc:creator: k.hitchner09
item.content:encoded:
If you’re new to climbing in general or just new to climbing outside, one way to really get the blood pumping is multi-pitch climbing. Unlike top-roping (where a rope runs from the belayer, through an anchor system at the top of the route and back down to the climber on the other end of the rope), multi-pitch climbing involves a “lead” climber climbing, placing “protection”( gear--namely cams, nuts, or ice screws) in the rock or ice along the way for protection from falling, and then building their own anchor system at the top of the “pitch”, from which they may then belay the next climber up to their stopping point.
The “pitch” length can be determined a few ways: a) by the length of the rope b) if there is a good stopping point--a well protected ledge making a good belay station or fixed bolts making easy anchor points. c) if the leader has run out of protective gear to place along the route. Multi-pitch climbing allows you to ascend climbing routes that are hundreds, even thousands of feet high. However, with this added adventure, there come many more risks so it is important to know a little bit about what to expect and how to prepare for a multi-pitch climb. While I won’t get into the specifics of rope handling and gear setting/cleaning here since it can be complicated and unique to the people with whom you decide to climb, I will give some general impressions and lessons from my first experience. My first multi-pitch rock climb was at Cathedral Ledge in North Conway, NH. This is a classic east coast climbing spot with 400ft of granite projecting up out of the Mount Washington Valley. After only climbing in the gym, the sheer amount of air below me was quite the shock. If you are someone who is affected by heights, staying relaxed and focused will likely be the biggest challenge mentally. On the flip side, this very fear is also the biggest rush! Here is what I brought with me: -Harness -Helmet -Climbing Shoes -Normal shoes (for the descent by foot afterwards- on multi-pitch climbs, you generally “ top out” meaning you don’t repel down but instead reach the top of the cliff and hike down to the base) -ATC and extra locking carabiners -Chalk Bag

-Energy bars

-Water

-Water resistant/proof shell ( it often gets cold or weather changes so its good to have this extra layer.)

What I borrowed/used that was not mine: -sling/webbing to hook into anchor -ropes -alpine draws -gear cleaner Note: This climb was done in the spring on a relatively warm day so if it were colder, your clothing choices would obviously be different. I put the water, food, shell, and descent shoes in a small light back pack. Sunscreen before climbing! Chances are youll be very exposed to the sun. Just looking at this list gives you an idea of some of the characteristics of multi-pitch climbing. The days can be long and the challenges facing climbers are slightly different. While you may climb lower rated climbs than your ability level, the frequency and speed at which you will be climbing will serve as ample challenge. Furthermore, you’ll be happy to have the extras like food to keep your energy levels up and your mind sharp because multi-pitch climbing requires much more interaction with your gear, whether you are a leader or a follower. The leader must place gear, set anchors, and belay the followers. The follower has to lead belay the leader, clean(take out) the gear placed by the leader, and undo the anchor before beginning to climb again. This said, a few warm up climbs on smaller routes can be extremely helpful not only to get your muscles warmed up but also to get in the zone mentally. All in all, even though I havent done much climbing, I would say multi-pitch is my favorite so far. While you may not always be doing the most challenging climbs or the most acrobatic moves, you’re going somewhere. Youre going up towards a peak, towards a great view, towards the sky. Not to mention, the great rush you get when you get when you look down not to gym mats 30 ft below but to rocks and forest hundreds of feet below. Rock on, (ha! get it?) Hitch

item.title: Ice Climbing for under $1000
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: In my last post I talked about having the opportunity to try out some awesome gear at last year's Ouray Ice Fest. The Women's La Sportiva Nepal EVO's that I climbed in were magic, and they should be considering that they retail normally for around $480. The Ice tools brand new cost around $300...each, and the crampons hang out around $150. We're talking more than $1000 worth of gear that you get to use one season a year. One day when I'm making the big bucks and climbing multiple times a week, these will be a good investment, similar to how I needed a good bike since I use it almost every day. But as a Junior in Boston, I'm ice climbing only 3-4 times a year if I'm lucky, making these shiny, sharp toys way out of my price range. Unfortunately, ice climbing is one of those sports that is impossible without the proper gear, for safety as well as just [caption id="attachment_140" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Forrrr Naarrrrnia!"][/caption] plain technical reasons (although I've heard of people using wool gloves to shimmy-up low angle ice. Apparently the wool freezes to the ice and sort of sticks to it...not recommended.) My first winter hike and ice climbing experiences were jammed into one weekend during my first February in the Northeast. I borrowed a pair of Scarpa Inverno Mountaineering boots from Tufts Mountain Club. They were a solid pair of boots, a little worn, and about a size and a half too big for me. Regardless, I was just excited to get outside in the cold and so I put on three pairs of wool socks, and took off on my first winter over night. The hike up wasn't bad, but the hike down the next day took a serious tole on my shins and toes. My big toes on both of my feet were numb with pain by the time we made it down, but I refused to take off my boots until I had at least tried ice climbing. I did two climbs, and then finally took my boots off. Four of my toenails were black, and I could barely walk for the next week. I remember brushing my toe up against a flip-flop, and instantly crying in pain. [caption id="attachment_141" align="alignleft" width="225" caption="Not quite sure what to do/if my toes would make it. Note the bike helmet..."][/caption] It took a few weeks for the pain to recede, and then about 6 months for them to finally fall off and start growing back. Real gross. Therefore, for the next winter, I kept my eyes peeled for a pair of mountaineering boots that would fit me. I set my price limit at $100 and started checking out craigslist every so often. I figured that having a pair of boots would be a good call, since they have multiple uses: winter hiking as well as ice climbing. Crampons and ice tools I could potentially borrow when needed, and usually the people I go with have an extra set. That winter I got really lucky when I borrowed a friend's mountaineering boots for a day of climbing. They are white, hard plastic, purple-laced, doubled booted beasts from at least the early 90's. The tops are a little beat up but the bottoms looked as if they had never been worn. She had bought them off of craigslist but they were half a size too big. I wore them for the day, and to my delight, they fit me perfectly. It took me a year, but this past December, I finally convinced her that these boots would have a loving home if she sold them to me. The best part? It only costed me $50. I don't care at all that they are not the lightest or warmest or newest model, what I care about is the fact that they fit me, allow me to ice climb and hike in the winter safely, and will allow me to keep all of my toenails. As far as crampons and ice tools? I'm still keeping an eye out for a good deal. Hit me up if you're selling any dirt cheap. -S [caption id="attachment_142" align="alignleft" width="225" caption="My sexy "new" boots. I think I'll spray paint them neon green and pink."][/caption]

item.title: Working in the Outdoors
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: As Spring semester starts moving into full gear, my familiar friends stress and anxiety have made their unwelcome way back into my day to day life. As if being a full time student wasn't enough, everyone around me is either talking about applying for internships, or where they are going to work when they graduate. Unfortunately (or fortunately), I tend to prioritize spending all of my free time during the week and weekends hiking or climbing. Many, including myself, occasionally think that there are no "resumé" building skills to be gained in the outdoors, but I am here to argue otherwise. I was once told by a wise mentor that if I can lead a group safely through the wilderness, I can sure as hell lead them in a board room. Whether or not this applies directly, you cannot discredit the leadership skills that you learn in the outdoors, whether as a camp counselor, or weekend trip leader. Start by joining your school's outdoor or mountain club and look for leadership opportunities within the club. Keep your eyes peeled for summer jobs at summer camps or as a summer caretaker. Guaranteed you'll have a fun and exciting summer outside, while also learning valuable skills. [caption id="attachment_164" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Day 2 of 8 wearing the same jeans."][/caption] Another thing to keep in mind is that being able to and enjoying getting and staying dirty is, believe it or not, a rarity. Not everyone is happy peeing outside and carrying around their own toilet paper. And few can successfully survive off of freeze dried food and protein bars. These were all skills that I found came in hand this past winter break when I was part of a health service brigade to Guatemala with Timmy Global Health. The details of the trip are perhaps better left to a separate post, but many NGOs, national and international service organizations value somebody who is not afraid to get down dirty, someone who doesn't particularly need a shower more than once a week. Along with looking fantastic on your resumé, these types of jobs and volunteer opportunities, whether they are during your breaks or after you graduate, will give you the opportunity to make the world we live in a little bit better of a place. Organizations such as Overland, Putney Student Travel, and The Road Less Traveled offer an opportunity to combine adventure with service. What programs have you been on that would fall under this category? Any recommendations?

item.title: Tips on Cold Weather Running
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: If you're anything like me, you despise gyms. They have only a couple of real uses in my book: a place to swim in the winter,  a pull up bar, and the occasional good looking person. Although running on a treadmill has its benefits (easier on the shins, a tendency to run faster) there is something to be said for getting out in the crisp winter air and dodging patches of ice on your run. Here's some tips to keep you warm and fast! The basic idea is that when you're running in the cold, you want to stay warm and dry using, if possible, only 2 or 3 layers. [caption id="attachment_179" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Tufts Marathon Team in 10 degree weather. Exercise gives you endorphins, endorphins make you happy!"][/caption] Avoid wearing cotton. Cotton is very absorbent and stays wetter, longer, and is heavier when wet, as compared to synthetic fabrics. Wearing wet cotton is more cumbersome and less comfortable than wearing wet/damp synthetics. You'll notice the difference especially with socks and t-shirts. You don't need fancy, expensive name brands to get the job done. Check out Target, Marshalls, etc for synthetic clothes. Layers: The innermost layer (shirt & pants next to your skin)should be a synthetic long underwear-type layer that wicks moisture away from your skin. This is a relatively thin layer. The outermost layer (exposed to the elements) should be a breathable wind barrier. A light micro fleece is what I use, but what you're really going to want is wind protection. Even a super thin wind or waterproof jacket (like your rain jacket) will work beautifully. Things too look for if you need to go and buy a wind layer: a hood, and pit zips (armpit zips) are clutch (read: awesome) for heat control. If it's super cold out, a light fleece might be best between those layers. Hats and gloves: Preferecnes vary of course, but a light synthtic hat or synthetic head band that covers your ears are essential. Your ears will get cold. I'm too hot will a full hat on and so a fleece head band work perfectly. A thin pair of gloves should work just fine, but if your hand get cold easier, mittens will keep your hands warmer than gloves. [caption id="attachment_180" align="alignright" width="300" caption="The Tufts Marathon Team. Note: running in cold weather without a shirt is not recommended."][/caption]   For more exercise and nutrition tips, check out Nancy Clark's website. She also has a phenomenal book that has changed my life.

item.title: The Benefits of Yoga as a Student
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: I've found myself in many conversations about yoga in the past month or so. Last semester I started attending classes once or twice a week that were taught by students at Tufts through Tufts Student Resources (TSR). I had done yoga sporadically over the years, mostly to accompany my mom, but I had never before attended so consistently. After about a year of doing yoga 2-4 times a week, I have become a hardcore believer in the physical and emotional benefits of the practice. Here are some reasons why I believe doing yoga even just once a week is crucial to your success as a college outdoorsman: [caption id="attachment_193" align="alignright" width="179" caption="AcroYoga at the Tufts Loj during VICEfest"][/caption] 1) Strength, Flexibility, Abs: Replacing one day of your gym routine with an hour of yoga may be just what you need to catapult you to the next level. There are three aspects to athleticism: Strength, endurance, and flexibility, and yoga can help you with all three. The flexibility you gain will help you prevent injuries during your weekend adventures, in addition to helping you solve that bouldering problem you've been working on. Even after not climbing for 3 months, I was able to climb as hard as ever thanks to these weekly practices. The upper and lower body work outs, in addition to all the holds and twists that work your core, will test your athletic ability, as well as tone your entire body. 2) Stress reduction: In our crazy fast life of working hard during the week, and playing hard on the weekends, stress can become a daily occurrence. Taking an hour to clear your mind and work your body can help not only with stress reduction, but with your general emotional wellness, enhancement of the immune system, and improved balance and postural alignment. This can be key, especially since as students, we sit in chairs all day long and rarely take a real break. I found myself looking forward to the one hour a week when I didn't have to think about anything. I always left the practice refreshed and ready to conquer. [caption id="attachment_189" align="alignright" width="199" caption="Kate doing a casual headstand before getting on the ice."][/caption] 3) Injury Prevention and Therapy: Needless to say, the harder you play, the more likely you are to get injured. I, personally, struggle from ankles weaker than paper and a high impact neck injury. More than a few times I've been stopped from hiking, climbing, and even running from these irritating facts of life. Even after months, heck, years of physical therapy, I would still roll my ankle and get headaches. But after about 6 months of yoga, my ankles started to strengthen (hello balancing postures) and my neck and back muscles became stronger and leaner, almost completely eliminating my daily headaches. There are of course dangers to plunging into a hardcore yoga routine, and like anything else, needs to be approached cautiously and slowly. There was recently an article in the NY Times titled "How Yoga Can Wreck Your Body", which may get you thinking about the potential risks of doing yoga. But, hey, there's risk in ice climbing too, you just have to learn how to make it safe for yourself, and then maybe you'll experience the benefits that I have! Take a look at Outside Magazine's response for a different perspective. All I can say, is that I've never been stronger or felt better. Check out your university's PE department to see if you can even take yoga for credit (I am this semester!) or keep an eye on sites like Groupon or LivingSocial. They're always giving away great deals on yoga classes.  -S

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I used to think that yoga was for people who couldn't do real sports. After being exposed to yoga through P90X in my junior year of college I became a firm believer in its benefits. I still wouldn't advocate for exclusively practicing yoga as your main athletic event but rather use it as a supplement to your strength, flexibility, and power training for other sports. As an athlete, how much you can bench press is pretty trivial(aside from maybe power lifting). Yoga helps build your core and gives you control over your body, very important for the sports I grew up playing (hockey, baseball, xc, rock climbing, etc). I seem to sweat more during a 60 minute yoga session than I do running 13 miles. If you've never done yoga, go try it out and I guarantee you'll be humbled.

I definitely agree with using Yoga as a supplement to the rest of your athletic endeavors. The P90X yoga video is pretty intense, but definitely not for beginners. I think that personal instruction when starting out yoga is key, and it's videos like those that may encourage injuries.

item.title: OR VersaLiner™ Glove - Gear Review
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: I know a lot about gloves. I have probably spent over half my lifetime in gloves: riding horses, stacking hay, pulling fences, skiing, biking, camping and prepping pizzas. I know that good gloves have to balance protection/warmth with dexterity and retained sensation. I also know that this fall, I found my favorite pair of gloves to date: The Outdoor Research (OR) VersaLiners. As the name implies, they are versatile. Here is a brief list of things you can do in them: -Run (in temps down to 18 degrees with or without precipitation) -Cycle (in temps down to 25 degrees (wind-chill not included) with or without precipitation) -Use your iPhone -Open latches on gates -Light a Whisperlight -Tie knots -Win a snowball fight -Carry a small fortune in the back-of-hand pocket -Ice climb -Break a colt to ride -Open things in wrappers (Clif Bars, Hand Warmers, Condoms etc.) -Wear them under gloves or mittens (even mittens with finger liners) Sick, right? Over the years, I have become a bigger and bigger fan of OR as a company. They make products that work, fit well, look good and hold up to substantial abuse. Their products are always simple and well designed, a cut above minimalist and several steps below the rocket ships that Mountain Hardwear usually produces. And these gloves are no exception. Specs: -100-weight Radiant Fleece™ liner fabric; smooth face, brushed back -Waterproof/breathable, 2.5 layer 40D Pertex® Shield DS stretch ripstop fabric -Zippered pocket on back of hand doubles as shell storage and heat pack pocket -Silicone prints on liner fingertips and palm provide solid grip and keeps liner in place under a shell -Reflective logo on shell OR says:             “When the weather turns suddenly uncooperative, the VersaLiner™ reverse modular gloves offer breathable insulation and waterproof protection for high-energy adventures. With a 100-weight Radiant Fleece™ insulating liner, and a removable waterproof and breathable Pertex® Shield DS stretch ripstop fabric shell, the VersaLiner™ protects hands from the weather while also transporting perspiration away from the skin. The zippered back-of-hand pocket - for shell storage - doubles as a heat pack pocket for when conditions turn unexpectedly icy.” MD 20/20 says: [caption id="attachment_204" align="alignright" width="225" caption="You can also bear hug trail signs in these gloves."][/caption] If you spend any amount of time outside in cold temps, buy them. I have used these gloves for everything from running a workout to ice climbing (in mild weather) to using a digital camera. They not only keep you warm, but if you pull the shells out of the handy-dandy back-of-hand pockets, they will keep you dry. And I was able wear them under a pair of mittens that had finger liners and still maintain enough dexterity to belay. Since this winter has been more of a spring, I have yet to test them under my mittens in extreme cold, but the combo feels like it would hold up. The back-of-hand pockets not only provide a home for the off duty shells, but credit cards, car keys, hand warmers and other odd and ends. The simple design makes them elegant enough to pair with your fur lined boots and Little Black Dress for those après ski activties. My favorite feature is the length of the cuff; I have yet to combine these with a shirt where I had a gap between glove and shirt. The palms and fingers have textured pimples that allow touch screen use and provide grip when pouring hot beverages. I bought them on sale form rei.com for $25.99, but they usually run $45. That being said, knowing what I know now, I would still buy them. They are only available men’s sizes, so ladies order down. I bought mediums and usually wear an 8.5 (for those of you who know glove sizes) and am quite happy with the fit, although I have big hands. Skip your morning latte for 10 days, put in 4.5 extra hours at your job or host a bake sale and then get you and your warm hands outside from some winter adventures! With love and warmth from your #1 gear hound, Mad Dawg

item.title: A Valentine's Day Disaster in the White Mountains
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded:
A year ago today I had planned a perfectly non-corny romantic weekend for my boyfriend Mike and I. Instead of our usual routine of going up to New Hampshire, doing something ridiculously exhausting all day, drinking a few beers and then passing out at night, I thought we would spend the weekend at the Tufts Loj getting some well deserved R+R. I bought the ingredients to make Beer Can Chicken for dinner with homemade sweet potato fries, and Nutella-raspberry crepes for dessert. We didn’t need to bring up all of our gear because all we were going to do was go on a little cross country ski and then hang out and enjoy being at the Loj. But then things changed. Sometime around the middle of the afternoon, the Loj caretakers were informed that my friend from the mountain club was lost with his brother somewhere near Mt. Kinsman and Mt. Cannon. The only other people at the Loj that weekend were a group of freshman, which meant that Michael and I were the most experienced people there, and so we volunteered to go out as first responders since the local search and rescue people were a couple of hours out. Here’s what we knew:
  • Our friend had lost his snowshoes, as well as both of his low top hiking boots. He only had cotton socks. His brother also lost his snowshoes. Apparently they got buried if 4-5 feet of snow when they got lost off of the trail. Our friend lost his boots by stepping into a stream which apparently sucked off his shoes and he couldn’t recuperate them.
  • They had forgotten to bring food, and didn’t have enough water.
  • They had not told anyone where they would be, and had mentioned that they might spend the night out. We were lucky that they were able to reach us, or else we would not have worried about them until the next day.
  • They had called someone else when they first were lost, but the Loj caretakers weren’t notified until a few hours after that first call.
  • We couldn’t reach them anymore since either their phone had died or they had lost service.
  • As of the last call, they were disoriented, lost and tired, most likely in early stages of hypothermia.
A number of things went wrong on the way to the trail head:
  • I did not have the proper clothing or gear to go out into the White Mountains, but I decided that I would anyways.
  • Our friend and his brother had not filled out a trips form and so we only had a rough idea where they might be; we weren’t even really sure what trails they took.
  •  We lost cell service on the drive up and so could not communicate with the caretaker who was the point of contact.
Luck would have it that we ran into the fish and game police in one parking lot, and they were able to set us up with proper first aid kits, walky-talkies, very powerful headlamps, and some warm clothing if we found the boys. In addition, Mike and I had brought a very warm sleeping bag and a bottle of hot water to warm our friend up if he was hypothermic, as well as some food. We made it over to the proper parking lot where we assumed they had started, although their car wasn’t there. I have never been so nervous in my life, knowing that I was unprepared, the temperature was dropping, and the sun was about to go down. What would we even do if we found them? By the time we ready to go, the full search and rescue crew had arrived, and so we were there to support their efforts and cover more ground. Just as we were about to split up and head out, I miraculously received a text message (we were in a no-service zone) that our friend had made it out a few minutes before us and they were on the way to the hospital. I have to give mad props to the caretaker that weekend, who, thanks to his EMT training, did an amazing job as the point person and making sure that everything was organized and executed in a calm and efficient manner. We were very lucky that he was up there that weekend. This episode will haunt me for a very long time. It was a classic example of a bunch of little things going wrong, and then eventually turning into a disaster, and putting many people’s lives at risk. Thankfully there was a very powerful response from the Tufts Mountain Club to put procedures in order to prevent a situation like this happening ever again. I believe that winter activities can be very fun, but they can also be very dangerous and demand a healthy amount of respect. The White Mountains are particularly dangerous since they are so accessible from highways and cities like Boston that many people don’t take them that seriously. However, they have some of the worst weather in the country, which is a deadly combination with naivety. Our friend was not an inexperienced outdoorsman; he had lots of summer and rock climbing experience, but they went out in February thinking it was just like August. There are somethings you can get away with in the summer that winter will be relentless about.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Freedom of the Hills Friday: Hypothermia Symptoms
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] I’ve only had mild hypothermia a couple of times, and changing into dry clothes and getting into a sleeping bag with another person usually does the trick. To see how hypothermia can affect your decision making process, check out this story of a pair of boys that were lost in the White Mountains in New Hampshire. [...]

Thanks for sharing, Mike and Sarah.
How did you make the call to set out despite feeling underprepared? Were you counting on your own judgement of when to turn back to keep yourselves from getting in to your own bad spot?
I'm also mystified by the idea of boots and snowshoes being instantly whisked away in a stream. A stark reminder of respect for winter water hazards.

The snowshoe situation was indeed mystifying. Apparently when they had gotten off the trail they encountered 5 foot deep snow. Their MSR snowshoes didn't keep them buoyant and as a result they got waist deep in snow more than a few times. The weight of the snow on top of the snowshoes pulled them off as they tried to get their legs unstuck from the powder. For whatever reason neither person was able to recover their snowshoes (they eventually paid back the TMC for lost property).
For the lost shoes, he had stepped through the snow into a stream. The water, snow, and slush sucked his boot off, much like stepping in the mud. This happened to both shoes and neither was recovered. So he walked out without his shoes on, in cotton socks. After several hours of this he and his brother managed to get to the highway and drive themselves to the hospital. Luckily, he ended up with severe frostbite on both feet and both hands, no digits were lost, spent time on pain killers and two weeks at home away from school recovering.
As for the preparedness for Sarah and I. We didn't have the appropriate gear either; summer hiking boots and non-water proof pants because we planned on a nice quiet weekend at the Tufts Loj. We decided to help for a few reasons.
1.) From his brother's last call to the Tufts Loj we knew they were between two points, on one of two trails only a few miles from the highway. At that point they were sitting down and resting and the one without his shoes was hypothermic, although not unresponsive, his brother didn't know what this meant.
2.) The rescue that was initiated came from North Conway, at least a 1 hour drive not counting prep time, so 2 hours was reasonable just to get to the trail head, let alone begin searching.
3.) Sarah and I were knowledgeable about the two trails, having hiked them several times both together and separately. Knowing it was only a few miles to where the two trails intersected, we felt confident that we could walk to the intersection and back without harm.
4.) When we showed up to the trail head, a Fish and Game warden was there with two rescuers from Canon Mountain right next door (luckily they were just getting off duty and volunteered to help considering the crew from North Conway was still hours away). We planned to split up, Sarah and I up one trail, the rescuers up the other, meet in the middle and then hike back down.
5.) We had a dry set of clothes/socks, a spare set of boots, a -40F darkstar sleeping bag, head lamps, some food, a warm thermos of water, first aid kit, space blanket, a radio to communicate with the other rescuers, etc.
All that aside we weren't well prepared either, it was dark, started to snow, and was around 15F and getting colder. Everyone's lives were in danger (even though we and the rescuers volunteered) because a few simple things were overlooked as mentioned in Sarah's post above. Luckily the boys made it out by themselves and to the hospital before someone died. Sarah and I had more than a few frank conversations about the likelihood of us finding him dead, or not finding him at all. I think about this situation every time I go out into a winter adventure. It's an unpleasant reminder of how a little bit of preparedness can go along way, but it's a reminder none the less.
Also we got a good lesson on not relying on your cell phone for help. We had spotty service and more often than not no service at all, so contact with the Tufts Loj was minimal if not non-existent.

Mike, I appreciate you adding details to the case. I think one of the more important lessons that came from the episode is the response that the Tufts Mountain Club had. They reinstated mandatory detailed trips forms, as well as updated the emergency response system and taught all the new caretakers the new procedures.

Crazy situation, glad everything turned out ok. I would imagine it be hard not to go out and help even if you aren't well equipped. I know if if I were in your situation I would go out but in the back of my mind I would be thingking "Don't turn this into a situation where they have to rescue you too."

Hindsight being 20/20, you can always say you might have done things differently. It sounds like you guys made the best choices with the info and gear you had. I'll close with one of my favorite quotes: "A great guide can build you a fire in a rainstorm. A master guide will build you a fire in a rainstorm, and then produce a bottle of scotch." -Les Stroud, 'Survivorman'

item.title: Sasha DiGuilian is First American Woman to Climb a 5.14d
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_265" align="alignright" width="200" caption="PC: http://www.sasha-digiulian.com/"][/caption] Sasha DiGuilian and I have a lot in common. We're both fit females that can't yet legally drink. We both like to exercise in pink sports bras, and we're both really competitve. Oh, except she's one of the best female climbers in the world right now. In case you were hiding under a rock last fall, this 18 year old blond girl made us all look really bad. On October 15th 2011, adidas team athlete, Sasha DiGiulian became the first American women to climb the grade 9a (5.14d) with her historic ascent of "Pure Imagination" in Kentucky's Red River Gorge. She's only the third woman ever to climb that grade. I realize that although this may be ancient history by now, I've found myself thinking about her a lot, and how she breaks all of the rules and excuses I've made for myself over the past couple of years. My first response after hearing about this accomplishment was jealousy. She was cute, blond, didn't take life too seriously, and climbed like a baller. But jealousy quickly turned to respect and self-reflection. I consider myself a jack of all trades. I've tried a lot of things, and am decent at most of them, but really good at none of them. I enjoy this part of myself. It allows me to have a wide range of friends, and to be able to play hard at whatever people around me choose to do. But I've never been the best. I've been thinking about whether or not I should have devoted my life (or at least my college life) to one thing. Should I have learned to climb and then given it all I had? I might have been able to create a name for myself, maybe even called myself a good climber. [caption id="attachment_266" align="alignright" width="199" caption="PC: http://www.sasha-digiulian.com/"][/caption] I look at Sasha and I think of the amazing things that someone can accomplish if they devote their life to it. Before I saw the video of her doing this climb, I used to think that I didn't have the "body type" to be a climber, whatever that meant. I'm not very tall, my strength to weight ratio isn't the best, I'm not old enough to have enough experience. All of these excuses were thrown out the window when I learned that Sasha is only 5'2" and was 18 years old when she climbed "Pure Imagination". So what does this mean to me? Maybe if I had started climbing at age 4, and maybe if my parents were climbers and had pushed me through my teenage years to continue climbing, maybe that could have been me. Maybe. But now that my dream of being the first American woman to climb a 5.14d is crushed, I can focus on more attainable goals. Being a student puts a damper on the amount of time I can truly dedicate to any outdoor endeavor, but Sasha gives me hope for the future. For now, I have my sights set on the half snowshoe marathon I'm running the weekend after next. That 5.15 I've been eyeing may just have to wait.     http://vimeo.com/33306702

item.title: Freedom of the Hills Friday: Hypothermia Symptoms
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded:
This post is the first of the weekly "Freedom of the Hills Friday". I bought a deck of Freedom of the Hills [caption id="attachment_271" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Best $5 I ever spent."][/caption] Playing cards, and so every Friday I'll pick a random card, and write about the lesson that is on that card. This week's card was a 7 of hearts on Hypothermia Symptoms: Hypothermia: Hypothermia results when the body's core temperature drops to 95° F (35°C) or lower. Risk factors include dehydration and prolonged exposure to wet clothing and wind. Prolonged exposure to wet, windy conditions is more likely than a sudden cold snap to lead to hypothermia.   Mild Hypothermia Symptoms (Body temp of 90-95°F/32-25°C): Symptoms include intense shivering, fumbling hand movements, stumbling, dulling of mental functions, uncooperative behavior (I know this as the “Umbles”: stumbles, mumbles, grumbles, fumbles). This stage is not seriously dangerous, but can progress quickly to severe hypothermia which is extremely dangerous. Hypothermia can be instigated even in 50°F weather if the victim is wet or if there is wind. Make sure to have a change of dry clothes and a rain jacket at all times. [caption id="attachment_273" align="alignright" width="225" caption="This is a good way to keep warm. Just make sure you put your puffy jacket on when you're done!"][/caption] What to do in the case of mild Hypothermia:
  • Eat and drink. Food=calories. Calories=heat.
  • Remove and replace all wet and/or cotton clothing, remembering that "cotton kills" (since it doesn't keep you warm when wet. Synthetic layers are a must).
  • Exercise in short bursts to generate heat. "Feed um and beat um."
  • Apply heat (like a warm water bottle) to neck, armpits and groin area.
Severe Hypothermia Symptoms (Body temp below 90°F/32°C):  Lack of shivering, obvious decline in muscle and nervous system function (muscles are stiff and movements uncoordinated), inability to walk, confused or irrational behavior, stupor or actual unconsciousness, fading pulse and respiration, dilated pupils. Treatment: Someone with severe hypothermia is in a critical situation. Get medical attention immediately; this should be your highest priority. In the mean time, the best thing to do it get protection from the elements and attempt to warm them up on the spot. Put the affected person in a sleeping bag or under a pile of blankets with one or two other people. Body heat can do wonders. Treat person very delicately and do not give them hot fluids to drink. I've only had mild hypothermia a couple of times, and changing into dry clothes and getting into a sleeping bag with another person usually does the trick. To see how hypothermia can affect your decision making process, check out this story of a pair of boys that were lost in the White Mountains in New Hampshire.  Has anyone ever had or seen severe hypothermia? What did you do? Were you trained to know how to treat it? (Sources: Freedom of the Hills, SOLO Wilderness Medicine)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I remember one time a friend and I had done a winter overnight on the Kinsmans. On our way down we stopped by to ice climb for a few hours with friends and then drove back to the Tufts Loj. She fell asleep on the 15 minute drive back and when she woke up at the Loj she was shivering uncontrollably. Because she had fallen asleep her body stopped producing as much heat and her pulse rate lowered dramatically, that combined with the damp clothes from climbing was a bad combo. However, after we put her in some dry clothes and she spent 5 minutes in a zero degree sleeping bag in the Loj she was fine, but it definitely shows how easy it is to slip into hypothermia especially when you're damp and tired.
Also, I like the phrase "Heat em, feed em, and beat em" when it comes to hypothermia symptoms. Heat them by putting on dry clothes (base layer, jacket, gloves, hat, etc), then Feed them (put down a cliff bar or some trail mix), and then Beat them (make them hike up and down a bit). Nothing like dry clothes, food, and exercise to warm you up from within.
Being protected from the elements is also key. Weather in the White Mountains can change rapidly and hypothermia cases happen even in the summer. I recall a summer prezi-traverse (2011) where it was 60 degrees but with 100% humidity and 40mph winds it was prime time hypothermia conditions if you're not careful.

item.title: Snowshoe Half-Marathon, Pittsfield VT
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded:
This weekend was the annual Peak Races Pittsfield snowshoe race in Vermont. Every year for 4 or 5 years Tufts has sent a strong group of undergraduates and alumni to represent and tear it up. Last year, I was in appalling shape, and barely made it through the "fun run" 10k. This year, I was manipulated into signing up for the half marathon. The way the race works is that each lap up the mountain is about 6.5 miles. At the top and bottom of the mountain is a food and water station and a few people to cheer you on. You can choose to do the Fun Run (1 lap), the Half Marathon (2 Laps), Full Marathon (4 laps),  Ultra-Marathon (100 miles, 15 laps), or Death Race. This year we camped out behind a Bikram yoga studio the night before in winter tents where I got to try out a Nemo -40• sleeping bag that a friend JLo (Jeffrey Longcor) had been testing. It rained freezing rain all night long, and we were preparing to have a miserable day running and hiking in sleet and snow while trying not to get hypothermia. [caption id="attachment_322" align="alignright" width="225" caption="Pre-race adrenaline. Bright colors make me race faster."][/caption] Here's what I brought to the race for the Half-Marathon:
  • For the race: warm base layers (top and bottom), micro fleece, rain jacket and pants, wool socks, hiking boots, snow shoes, gaiters (works to keep your feet marginally drier during the race), gloves, hat, and a couple power bars/Gu.
  • For after the race: A whole change of dry clothes (socks, shoes, pants, shirt, underwear), down jacket, beer.
Luck was with us, and it ended up being a clear, rain free race day. Our strategy was to run/jog the flats and down hills, and fast hike the uphills. The race was awesome, but the best part was sitting around the bonfire afterwards, waiting for our friends to finish the marathon. We watched the Death Racers do 1,000 burpees, jump in the freezing river, and then do another 1,000 burpees. As Mike B would say, it's definitely a place to feel like a boy among men (or women, whatever). What is the Death Race you may ask? According their website, the course is "TBA - You can expect barbed wire, mud boggin, wood choppin, tunnels, deep water diving, running, crawling, crying, screaming, and sweating. Doubtful you'll finish but be proud of yourself for trying." Essentially, from an outsider's perspective, they make you do what ever they feel like, while taunting you and doing everything in their power to make you quit. [caption id="attachment_323" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Champion marathon snowshoers. "The banana suit messes up my layering system.""][/caption] In any case, although I felt pathetic next to the Death Racers and the 80 year old man who ran the 100 miler, I was proud of myself for finishing the Half Marathon. Most of it was probably due to doing the race with my friend Kate who kept me going up on the second lap when my hip-flexers were yelling STOP! I highly recommend doing one of these "alternative" races (snowshoe races, death races, spartan races, tough mudder, etc). It's a great way to spend a weekend, and people will think you're crazy when you tell them what you did.
