item.title: Freedom of the Hills Fridays: Mountain Features
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: Freedom of the Hills Fridays continues today with a little vocabulary lesson in mountain features. These are terms that seasoned mountaineers and climbers throw around, leaving the rest of us feeling like they're speaking a different language. But now, next time you're reading a Jon Krakauer adventure, you can nod in appreciation as he talks about the massive dihedrals and cols that he had to conquer. Heck, next time you're on a date, don't be afraid to mention that large talus slope you scrambled up. Nothing gets a girl going more than talus slopes. Arrête: Sharp crested ridge. [caption id="attachment_344" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Bergschrund"][/caption] Bergschrund: Giant crevasse at the upper limit of glacier movement, formed where a moving glacier breaks away from an ice cap or snowfield above. Chimney: Crack wide enough to fit a climber's body and narros enough to allow for opposing forse to be applied to both walls. Col: Saddle or pass. Crevasse: Chasm that splits a glacier. Dihedral: Where two walls meet in approximately a right-angled inside corner; also called an open book.  Moat: Gap between snow and rock. Moraine: Mounds of rock and debris deposited by a glacier. [caption id="attachment_345" align="alignright" width="225" caption="Chimney at Rumney, Parking Lot Wall."][/caption] Objective Hazard: Physical hazard associated with a route (e.g., rockfall, exposure, high altitude). Off-Width: Crack that is too wide for a hand jam but too narrow for chimney technique. Scree: Loose slope of small rock fragments Talus: Rock fragments big enough to step on individually (larger than scree).   Happy Friday! S

item.title: Working Outdoors...In the Name of Science!
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: Almost every student who is in love with the outdoors is constantly juggling that passion with more professional and scholarly obligations. Since only a very small percentage of us will go on to live the dream, becoming professional climbers, guides, and photographers, the rest of us are left searching for a way to contribute to society, while having a good time as well. Every once in a while, however, a perfect opportunity seems to present itself. The NY Times yesterday had an article called "Matches Made in the Wilderness, in the Name of Science" (check out the article for a sweet video). Essentially, it's about an organization called Adventurers and Scientists for Conservation and they recruit student volunteers to go on mini expeditions to collect data. [caption id="attachment_391" align="alignright" width="350" caption="PC: NYTimes, http://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/12/us/matching-adventurers-with-scientists.html?_r=2&emc=eta1"][/caption] So why students? Why target outdoorsman to help with scientific research? According to Mr.Trenish, the program founder, "“Every single day there are tens of thousands of people who are outside getting after it,' said Mr. Treinish, 30, who was named a 2008 National Geographic Adventurer of the Year for trekking the length of the Andes. 'They’re going to these places that researchers wish that they could get to.'” It seems like a win-win situation. Researchers get to save time and money by recruiting these volunteers, and outdoorsman get the opportunity to give back and support the areas they frequent the most. Plus, this system allows students to be introduced to field research in a fun way, even if they're not majoring in a scientific discipline. There is research to be done in almost every activity that you could think of: hiking, skiing, biking, kayaking, and gliding. I would highly recommend checking it out. Perhaps on your next backcountry snowshoeing trip, you could be tracking Wolverines too!

item.title: Freedom of the Hills Friday: Cougar Encounters
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: We often talk about what you should do in case you should happen upon a bear on the trail. The advice is confusing: run, don't move, make lots of noise, stay quiet, hit him with a stick, or gently pet him. When it comes down to it, I would have no idea what to do if I ever saw a bear approaching me, black, brown or otherwise. The good news is, after today, we'll all know what to do if a cougar suddenly decides to make friends with us. [caption id="attachment_399" align="alignright" width="298" caption="But look how cute they are! How could I possibly hit one with a stick? I'd rather take them home..."][/caption] Cougars, sometimes known as panthers or mountain lions, have more recently been seen in the Eastern US, in states such as Maine, Vermont, New York, and Michigan, as well as in the Adirondak and Catskills mountains and areas of California as well. According to Panthera.org, the cougar has "has the largest geographic range of any native terrestrial mammal in the Western Hemisphere." However, they are threatened by habitat loss and fragmentation, and over hunting by humans. Although they are beautiful and majestic animals, please resist to urge to pet or snuggle with them. The opposite goes as well: please don't shoot them. Instead, here are some tips on what to do when confronting a cougar from Freedom of Hills. Dont' Run:  Running may elicit a chase response in the cougar, and you can't outrun a cougar. [caption id="attachment_400" align="alignright" width="282" caption="Good luck proving your dominance."][/caption] Face the Cat: appear aggressive and large, waving your arms or jacket. Maintain eyeconact. Slowly Back Away, if safe to do so. Never turn your back on a cougar. Shout loudly at the cat. Fight back aggressively. Whack the animal with your trekking pole if it gets close enough. Most cougar attacks are predator-prey attacks. If you seems like a strong predator instead of prey, the cougar will likely back down. Good Luck! -Sarah

item.title: Petzl E+Lite®
item.dc:creator: Mad Dawg
item.content:encoded: From cooking a late night dinner to embarking on early morning alpine climbs, headlamps are an essential piece of gear for the outdoor enthusiast. You will, at some point in your life, find yourself out after dark or up before first light. Whether this is intentional or due to poor planning, having a headlamp can not only give you more hours to play, but could quite possibly save your life. The $29.99 Petzl E+Lite® is immediately attractive to the college student if for no other reason than its price tag. Unlike many low-cost items out there, this is a highly functional, highly dependable piece of gear. Marketed on the Petzl website under “emergency lighting”, this little lamp can do a whole lot more than get your back. The fully adjustable lycra-blend head strap allows the E+Lite to be worn on almost any part of your body, from your head down to your thigh; just in case you forgot to pack the garter strap for your backcountry wedding. The clip on the back of the lighting unit allows you to attach the unit the edge of a pot or brim of a hat and the three bulbs and five different settings provide light for every occasion, emergency or not. The emergency whistle that functions as the keeper on the headband can be heard from up to 500 meters away, and comes inscribe with an SOS Morse code illustration, in case you haven’t seen Titanic.   Here are the official tech specs: Bulb type: LED Bulb detail: 3 LEDs/ 1 red LED Red light mode: Yes Beam type: Flood Max light output: 16 Lumens Max beam distance: 19 meters Beam distance: High: 19/ Low: 11 meters Brightness levels: 3 Strobes: 2 Average run time: High: 35/ Low 45 hours Regulated output: No Rechargeable: No Batteries: 2 CR2032 Materials: Plastic Dimensions: 1.75 x 1.25 x 0.75 inches Weight with batteries: 0.98 oz/28 g I have used this headlamp while running, camping, reading, braiding my horses mane and on numerous occasions to find things in the dark depths of my dorm room. My favorite feature is the red light mode, which allows you to retain your night vision while tying your shoe or checking the map. At times I have found myself wishing that the beam had a greater max distance. The headband is fully adjustable and can be worn over/under hats, ear warmers and helmets of all shapes and sizes. At purchase, the E+Lite comes in a small, hard plastic case that is better suited to storing bobby pins and illegal substances then keeping your E+Lite safe. Unpacking and repacking it is not worth the time or effort, so I generally keep mine looped to the outside of my backpack or dangling from the rearview mirror of my approach vehicle. For a lightweight, multi-purpose light, the E+Lite is hard to beat. That being said, I have found myself wishing at times that the beam had a greater max distance and the unpadded plastic backing can get uncomfortable if you start to sweat, but if you don’t ask it to do the job of a full-sized headlamp, I think you will be quite happy. The only thing I truly hate about it is that it is not rechargeable, but that is because I hate using tiny screwdrivers. As a final note, anyone who is working to assemble a serious backcountry first aid kit, I would list this as an essential piece of gear, as you can never have too much light when things go south. This little light will get your camp set up, your lentils boiled and your nighttime story read. It just won’t get you up to your high alpine summit. Regardless, the E+Lite is a great deal and rumor has it you can find them as cheep as $23 on backcountrygear.com. With love and warmth from your #1 gear hound, Mad Dawg

item.title: Freedom of the Hills Friday: Dehydration
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: If you've ever felt low on energy, headache-y, lethargic, or dizzy, chances are you're probably dehydrated. The average person needs about 2-3 liters of water a day, in their day to day life. But once you start adventuring, you're going to need to start guzzling a lot more than that. You lose water through your sweat, your breath, and other bodily functions, which are greatly increased while exercising. Staying hydrated can not only help you prevent injury, but can help you perform at your top level. [caption id="attachment_417" align="alignright" width="300" caption="This is what dehydration looks like."][/caption] Here's what Freedom of the Hills has to say about it: Always begin mountaineering outings well hydrated. Drink a cup of water or its equivalent 15 minutes before starting out. (Hydrating the day before is just as important.) Once uderway, continue drinking fluids at a rate of 1-1.5 cups (.2-.3 liter) every 20-30 minutes. Don't rely on your sense of thirst as a gauge; drink before you feel thirsty. (As my momma used to say, if you feel thirsty, it's already too late.) If you don't need to urinate periodically, or if your urine color become unusually dark, you aren't drinking enough. (I like to remember the 3 C's of hydration: Clear, Copious, and Frequent.) [caption id="attachment_418" align="alignright" width="240" caption="CamelBaks, or any type of water bladder, are a great way to constantly drink water while you're moving. Beware of the tube freezing in the winter."][/caption] Commercial sports drinks aren't necessary, though they can help make fluid replacement more palatable. Juices, if used, should be diluted by at least 50 percent to prevent diarrhea. Electrolytes (body salts) lost through sweating can be replaced by eating snacks that have some salt content (or just have a cup of noodles. There's enough salt in that to last you a lifetime.) Maintaining good hydration reduces the risk of heat-related illness, cold-related illness (including frostbite), and altitude illness. Your overall physical performance will imporve dramatically too! Keeping all of these in mind, be wary of hyponatremia—"essentially, intoxication caused by consuming too much water, a ­potentially fatal condition in which cells swell with the excess fluid." My final two cents: it's easy to remember to drink water when it's hot out, but you lose as much water in cold weather too. Although you may not feel as thirsty or as sweaty, keep drinkin'! -Sarah Sources:  http://www.wms.org/news/altitude.asp http://www.outsideonline.com/fitness/endurance-training/Myth-6.html Mountaineering: The Freedom of the Hills, 8th Edition

item.title: How To Fill Your Gear Closet Without Going Broke
item.dc:creator: Mad Dawg
item.content:encoded:
People are in to gear. In to how it looks, how it performs, what it’s made out of, how much it cost, and who made it. Not who, as in the name of the factory worker or craftsman, but who, as in Mountain Hardware, Outdoor Research, Arc’teryx, Black Diamond, etc. Quality is important, but very few gear heads will test multiple products to find the best one, so most decisions are based on brand reputation and advertising. This means that people who consider themselves “hardcore” or “badass” are probably more likely to buy some piece of North Face gear that Alex Honnold is pedaling then an REI generic, regardless of price or quality. I seriously doubt that Ed Viesturs spent his younger years bumming around in a $569 North Face Mountain Manor, and I am 100% sure of the fact that buying one from him will not do a single thing to improve your climbing or your “badass” factor. This is less of a gear review and more of a lesson in why it is important to be a smart consumer. Just because it is made by a big name brand and big time badass is using it in a sexy ad doesn’t mean that it is the right piece of gear for you. It is easy to get fooled into thinking that you need the best possible item avalible, but the reality of it is we are in college. The best is nice to dream about and to fondle in the outlet stores, but we just don't have the bank accounts for it. Don't buy a tent that will work just in case you decide to summit Mt. McKinley before you graduate, buy a tent that will work for all your weekend trips. When you have the tickets paid for, the guide service booked and your fitness level up to snuff, then check out the NEMO Moki or the Mountain Hardware Trango and send me some summit photos. 

  Most of the time, there is a cheaper alternative that works just as well and looks just as good. The best tent I have ever owned is a $30 Coleman Sundome® 6 Tent (Note: Does not look at fly as a MH tent, but I stay dry). This tent has stayed standing in winds in excess of 70 mph and weathered a Rocky Mountain hailstorm. And it cost a fraction of Mountain Hardware Trango. I got lucky. I had no prior knowledge of this tent when I bought it, and it worked out great. Not everyone is this lucky and it can be hard to know when you are getting a lemon, so here is a short list of often cheaper options and what I know about them. When in doubt, go by word of mouth and always give yourself a margin for error. If you always bring along something that is capable of doing more than the task at hand, you will avoid a lot of accidents and near misses. Cheap alternatives to Patagucci, Mountain Haute Couture and The North Face: Never Stop Spending. Stoic: Literally the shittiest gear. I have only heard bad things. L.L Bean: I love their parkas and rain coats. Not as technical as some brands, but you don’t need all the engineering (and money) that goes into a Patagonia alpine jacket for a day hike. Also, they have an iron-clad guarantee. No matter what, you can always return your gear if it breaks or if you don't like it. Coleman: LOVELOVELOVE, obviously. Tents, sleeping bags, stoves, lanterns, camp chairs, the works. Not a huge selection of backpacking/climbing gear, but for hiking out of a car/cabin-based base camp, their stuff is hard to beat. REI: Ehh, this is a tough call. For the most part, I really like their base layers and their tents aren’t too shabby. My biggest complaint is I don’t find REI brand gear to be enough cheaper for me to take a gamble on something that is not guaranteed. On the plus side, they have a great return policy and stuff at their garage sales are hard to beat. EMS (Eastern Mountain Sports): As a newcomer to the east coast, I was skeptical, but they have toed the line thus far. They also give 15-20% discounts on all products for college students so that is a plus. Colombia: Not a huge savings, but I do like their fleeces and tech/cargo pants. Do you have a favorite discount brand that I didn't mention? Or maybe a favorite piece of cheap gear? Share your saves & splurges with your #1 gear hound, -Mad Dawg

item.title: Mini Adventures: Dates and Towers
item.dc:creator: k.hitchner09
item.content:encoded: During your four years at Tufts, there will come a time when you’ve got a date with that cute girl in TDC or the guy you met in your history class . Most people would ask for a coffee date at Hotung or maybe if they are feeling adventurous, grab some ice cream off campus at JP Licks... but you aren’t most people and you now have access to some of the best kept secret date spots around Tufts and Boston. These are for use at sunset, sun rise, preferably with some sort of picnic, and if you’re feeling extra romantic, a bottle of wine. [caption id="attachment_455" align="aligncenter" width="509" caption="View from the Fells Tower"][/caption] Theme of the week: Towers! · Observation Floor at the top of the Prudential building—Just a quick ride away on the Green Line (get off at the Hynes Convention Center stop), you get a 360 view of Boston. It is open until 10pm from March until October and until 8pm during the winter months. The only downside is that it costs $12 for students but it is worth doing at least once! Inside tip: it says it closes at 10pm but the last elevator up is at 9:30pm so don't miss it! [caption id="attachment_456" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Wright Tower at the Middlesex Fells"][/caption] · Observation Tower at Mt. Auburn Cemetary—Mount Auburn Cemetery is not only the resting place of many famous historical characters, well known for its diverse collection of trees, but it is also an ideal view spot for the Boston skyline. It is just 5 minutes from Tufts by car but if that’s not possible, the best way to get there is by bike. There are bike racks where you can lock your bikes while you walk to the Tower at the center of the cemetery. It is free entry but be sure to get there before 6pm when they close! And double check the website before going because their hours change with the seasons! · Wright Tower at the Fells—The Middlesex Fells Reservation is easily one of the best kept secrets around Tufts and therefore it is crucial that you know about it immediately! Just a couple miles or several minutes away from Slummerville, you’ll find yourself immersed in a 2,575 acre forest with two observation towers, a pond, a reservoir, and endless trails! This is the ideal spot for a trail run, mountain biking, some rock climbing if you find the right spots, or just a nice afternoon walk. Since we are talking dates, though, you can’t miss the Wright Tower. It is just a 5-10 minute walk (read: you won't get sweaty in front of your date) a trail from the parking lot to a tower with a view over the Boston Skyline and out to western Mass. Enjoy! -Kate

item.title: Freedom of the Hills Friday: The Climbing Code
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded:
In order to avoid being that asshole climber, there a few things to be aware of before chalking up for your first multi-pitch climb. Most are unspoken rules, and relatively intuitive, but here are a couple of guidelines to get you started. Follow these, and you'll be sure to have a stellar and, more importantly, safe climb. [caption id="attachment_467" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Buddy system! PC: Jeffrey Longcor"][/caption] The Climbing Code (according to Freedom of the Hills):
  • Leave a trip itinerary with a responsible person. These should include names, phone numbers, and emergency contacts of all members, as well as a detailed description of your trip and "freak out" time.
  • Carry necessary clothing, food, and equipment at all times.
  • A climbing party of three is the minimum, unless adequate prearranged support is available. On glaciers, a minimum of two roped teams is recommended.
  • Rope up on all exposed places and for all glacier travel. Anchor all belays.
  • Keep the party together, and obey the leader or majority rule.
  • Never climb beyond your ability and knowledge.
  • Never let judgment be overruled by desire when choosing the route or deciding whether to turn back.
  • Follow the precepts of sound mountaineering as set forth in books of recognized merit.
  • Behave at all times in a manner that reflects favorably upon mountaineering, including adherence to Leave No Trace principles.
The way I see it, tell someone where you're going, go with a friend, don't be a jerk, and don't be stupid. Climb on! -S Sources: Mountaineering: The Freedom of the Hills, 8th Edition

item.title: Spring Break: Climbing Adventures in the Red River Gorge
item.dc:creator: arosenthall
item.content:encoded: I never thought I would venture to Kentucky for spring break. While most of my peers jetted off to Mexico or Europe or back home for a week of academic respite, I embarked on a 16-hour drive to the Bluegrass state. What is in Kentucky, anyway? [caption id="attachment_484" align="alignright" width="256" caption="View of rocks at The Red"][/caption] Upon telling people my spring break plans, I was asked this question a lot. It is a legitimate question. Kentucky is not the typical spring break location. Well there is some bluegrass music, a lot of cow pastures, and the extraordinary rock-climbing mecca, The Red River Gorge, or commonly known as The Red. Red River Gorge is a massive canyon system located in east-central Kentucky. It is chock-a-block full with bolted sandstone cliffs, making it an ideal destination for rock climbers. Climbers from all over the world travel to The Red to improve their climbing and set new records. Just last October, 19-year-old Sasha DiGiulian became the first female climber to lead a 5.14d climb in The Red. The place is a big deal in the climbing world. [caption id="attachment_485" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Not quite my level of climbing...but it's there!"][/caption] I am fairly new to rock climbing. I have been climbing at an indoor gym for around 6 months and my trip to the Red was my first real, outdoor climbing experience. Even though I was not ascending hard grades in the Red, I still had a phenomenal time climbing mellow routes. Now, after a solid week of a climb-climb-climb mindset, I am dangerously addicted. The whole atmosphere within the Red is strangely peaceful – climbers from all over the world unite to explore Kentucky rock. There are waterfalls, natural bridges, and pastures that encompass the sandstone cliffs. The Red is a bubble world for enthused climbers. I went on the trip with 23 others – some very savvy climbers who have scaled the famous Yosemite wall El Capitan and others new to the game like me. Over the course of the week, I was fortunate enough to learn from climbing veterans skills ranging from lead climbing to trad cleaning to proper climbing lingo (I now add “bomber” as a descriptor for an awesome hold). While the trip was an incredible introduction to outdoor climbing, it was also inexpensive. The costs of the trip amounted to gas, lodging, food, and drink. As I mentioned before, it is about a 16-hour drive from Boston to the Red. It is a long way. I drove down 5-people to a 5-person car and drove back a leisurely 4-people to a 5-person car. It was a bit cozy but what better ways are there to bond with fellow climbers?  For the round trip, my share of gas expenses ended up being a little under $100. The cost was definitely less than most airfares and brought me to a whole other geographic region of the United States. The typical lodging for budget climbers in the Red is to pack a sleeping bag and tent and pay $2 a night to camp at a site called Miguel’s. Miguel’s is also a pizza and rock climbing shop and has become a famous hub for climbers in the Red. Chances are if someone’s going to the Red, they’re staying at Miguel’s. At two bucks a night it is completely affordable – and the pizza is delicious. Instead of lodging at Miguel’s my crew rented a cabin for the week through a company called Scenic Cabin Rentals. It cost $1800 for the full week. Between all of us, we each paid around $80. We rotated who slept on beds and couches and in sleeping bags and it worked really well. For post-climbing entertainment, there was a hot tub and pool table in the cabin. While this lodging was a bit more expensive than camping at Miguel’s, it was totally worth the extra money to take showers, have a kitchen, and relax in the hot tub. The third greatest expense was food – and booze. The organizers of my trip did a big grocery trip to BJs before the trip and stocked up on dirtbag staples like peanut butter, cheese, cereal, granola bars, beans, and bread. It saved us a lot of money to not buy groceries there and it was satisfying to prepare our own meals. For a climbing break, a few members of our group drove out to the Kentucky Ale brewery in Lexington, Kentucky to bring back a generous supply of Kentucky Ale for the cabin. There is no better way to complete a day of climbing than with a cold Kentucky Bourbon Barrel Ale. I ended up paying $100 for a week’s worth of food and beer. My spring break cost me under $300. I enjoyed the beauty of Kentucky. Best of all, I had an incredible time learning to climb and soaking up the climbing lifestyle. Give me the Red over Cancun any spring break. [caption id="attachment_486" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Another view of a crag in the Red"][/caption]   -Alexa

item.title: P-Cord, the Multi-Use and Essential Piece of Gear
item.dc:creator: Mad Dawg
item.content:encoded: Ever need to tie up a bear bag? Ever wished you could attach your spoon to your mug? Ever camped in high winds and need to stabilize your tent? If you answered yes to any of these questions, then you need P-Cord. After a good knife and a lighter, P-cord is the most essential piece of gear to pack for any sized adventure. History: P-Cord, formally known as Parachute Cord, also known as 55o cord, was first used during World War II in the suspension lines of US military parachutes. It didn’t take long for paratroopers to realize it had countless other uses in the field. The braided sheath has a high number of interwoven strands that give it a smooth texture in hand and the all-nylon constrctions makes it fairly elastic, which, depending on the task at hand, is either an asset or a liability. A single length has been tested to handle 550 lbs  of weight.                             Uses: -Belt -Attach things to your pack -Attach thing to your person -Attach things to your car -Attach things to others packs or cars -Repair torn clothing: dissect outer sheath to get an individual thread -Tow rope -Clothes line -Shoe laces -Zipper pull -Dental floss: dissect to get an individual thread -Leash (dog, rabbit, or child) -Tie up a person -Rig a trip wire -Make pulley system -Make faisonable and functional bracelets -Secure tents -Practice knots Need more ideas? http://www.Stormdrane.blogspot.com/ (Check out the suspenders) Need to learn some knots? http://www.animatedknots.com/ Where to get it: -REI $4.50/50 ft -EMS $4.95/50 ft -Sportsman’s Warehouse $3.29/60 ft -Military Supply Stores $8.99-$12.00/100 ft -The interwebs $3 and up   XOXO -Mad Dawg

item.title: Mini Adventures: Water
item.dc:creator: k.hitchner09
item.content:encoded: This weeks Mini-Adventures from Tufts are for all you water lovers out there. Whether you're looking for a swim, sail, kayak, or long walk on the beach, all of these are within spitting distance of Boston, and perfect for an afternoon or weekend adventure. Mystic Lake— Upper Mystic Lake, the practice location of Tufts’ very own Sailing team, is the perfect place to get away from the heat on a warm fall or spring day (and most definitely summer if you are around!). It is just 3.5 miles away from campus and one of the cleanest lakes in Massachusetts. You may get there by car, bike, or if you’re feeling ambitious, running (you can jump in the water to cool off once you get there). During the fall and spring, you may catch a sailing regatta on the weekends. However, the best time for swimming is late summer or early fall when the water is like a bath tub and way warmer than the ocean! It’s a great place to kayak, do swimming training for triathlons, or go for a sail if you can find someone who will take you for a ride. Crane Beach - This beach is a year-round favorite. Located on the north shore in Ipswich, MA, it’s a slightly complicated/weather-dependent trip without a car (Red Line+ Green Line +North Station+Newburyport/Rockport Commuter Rail line+bike 5 miles to the beach) but with a car, it is just under an hour to get there and it is worth the trip! About a ½ mile before hitting the beach, you’ll pass Russell Orchards, a crucial pit stop. You can stop here to pick up picnic food for your afternoon at the beach, go strawberry or apple picking depending on the season, get ice cream and homemade fudge, or my personal favorite: grab a dozen of their home made hot apple cider donuts (the best donuts you will ever taste). From here you can make your way to the beach but be sure to check out the prices. It can be pricey as a non-member since the beach is also a reservation. You can really make a day of the trip by checking out the Crane Estate, a mansion on the hill next to the beach. If you have the time, the mansion and grounds are stunning and worth taking a stroll around. Halibut Point- While Halibut Point State Park is probably not worth a trip in itself, it is worth mentioning so that you can tack it on to another trip up to the north shore (like the one to Crane beach!). With views from Massachusetts up to Maine, sun rise and sun set are the most ideal times to hit the view spot, which is just a 5 minute walk from the parking lot. It’s the perfect way to begin or end the day! Castle Island Gazebo- Castle Island is part of the Metropolitan Park System of Greater Boston (I bet you didn’t know Boston even had a park system...) and is located in South Boston in Boston Harbor. It’s a T and bus ride away from Tufts or about 30 minutes on a bike and offers a great view of Boston Harbor, the other islands, and sail boats racing in regattas in between! The island has a running/walking loop around the bunker, a beach, and a perfect gazebo view spot at the edge of the inner body of water, Pleasure Bay (yes, that’s its real name-you heard it here first). This is a great trip to do using TuftsBikes on a free weekend and you can follow it up by grabbing dinner in Boston on the way back!   Sources: http://www.thetrustees.org/places-to-visit/northeast-ma/crane-beach-on-the-crane.html http://www.bostonharborwalk.com/placestogo/location.php?nid=6&sid=44 http://www.mass.gov/dcr/parks/northeast/halb.htm

item.title: Freedom of the Hills Friday: How to Poop in the Woods
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: This article is more directed at those of you gifted enough to actually be able to relieve yourself when out on a long hike. Others of us suffer for a few days, praying for an outhouse, or even a tree stump that resembles a toilet seat. Don't get me wrong, I'm not exactly a modest person. I have more more than once smiled and waved at somebody as they walked by me doing number 1 not far enough off the trail. Perhaps it's a mental block to not be able to do the former. Anyways, I digress. How to Poop in the Woods:  Freedom of the Hills: Choose a site at least 200 ft  (60 m) away from watercourses, trails, and campsites. If it's easy for you to reach, it will be for others too! When finished, tamp soil down and scatter with vegetation to create a natural appearance. Pack out toilet paper.  Many campsites, at least along the AT, will have compostable outhouses (brilliant really, the compost keeps the odor down). But if you find your self running out of time in the middle of a trail, drop your pack and hustle far enough away to keep fellow hikers at bay. I also highly recommend bringing some sort of toilet paper. Leaves can work in a dire situation, but are you 100% sure that's not poison ivy? Baby wipes are also a phenomenal investment, especially for longer trips. Oh, and fiber bars. :) -S

item.title: How To Fill Your Gear Closet Without Going Broke: Part II
item.dc:creator: Mad Dawg
item.content:encoded: This week I will review sources for getting brand-name, high-end, gear at discount prices. The best way to do this is to buy your gear online, which allows you to price shop with ease. Many of the sites listed below have an app available for your smart phone, which allows you to track gear deals while on adventures. WIN.   Tracking Sites: These sites track deals from a wide variety of sites across the web (although you usually cannot purchase directly from them). http://www.cleansnipe.com/ -Tracks ODAT/DOD sites -Great resource for browsing ODATs/DODs -Searchable database that redirects you to site where product is available -@cleansnipe http://www.gearscan.com/ -Tracks ODAT/Deal of the Day (DOD) sites -Not as wide a variety of ODATs/DODs as CleanSnipe -Searchable database that redirects you to site where product is available -@gearscan http://www.thecheapoutdoors.com/ -Not as sexy looking as CleanSnipe and GearScan -Tracks sales, not just items (i.e. 30% of all Patagonia at ems.com) -@cheapoutdoors   Invite Only: Sites where deals are available to members only. item.title: Yoga for Climbers
item.dc:creator: arosenthall
item.content:encoded: Inhale, bump, exhale, lock off, inhale, heel hook, exhale, clip in. Relax. Om. Yoga and climbing have a lot in common. Both require you to calm your mind, work hard, and find your edge. The activities are perfect complements for one another – both supporting variations of strength, balance, and calm. Whether stuck in a sweaty Warrior 3 or on a heinous crimp, you learn to take a deep breath and push yourself to the next pose or move. Here is an assortment of yoga poses you can do to enhance your climbing abilities and train your mental stamina for the rock ahead! I have also included the Sanskrit pronunciation of the poses so you can impress your climber-yogi friends with your ancient language mastery. [caption id="attachment_544" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="This could be you!"][/caption]   Open up the Hips Kapotasana (Cap-poh-TAHS-anna)- Pigeon Pose Begin on all fours in a tabletop position (wrists under shoulders and knees under hips). Slide your right knee behind your right wrist and try to work your right shin in line with the front edge of your yoga mat. Slowly extend your left leg out behind you and uncurl your toes. Distribute your weight evenly between your hips and walk your hands out in front of you to rest your elbows or shoulders on the ground. You should feel a pretty intense stretch in your right hip. Repeat on the other side. [caption id="attachment_540" align="aligncenter" width="248" caption="Pigeon Pose"][/caption]   Stretch the Hamstrings Uttanasana (OOT-tan-AHS-ahna) - Standing Forward Bend Stand tall with your hands by your sides and shoulders down. As you exhale, bend forward from your hip joints and allow your head to come towards the ground. Continue to breath and release any tension from your neck and shoulders to get a deeper stretch. You should feel a deep stretch in the backs of your legs. [caption id="attachment_541" align="aligncenter" width="248" caption="Standing forward bend. For shoulder stretch: interlace hands behind back and allow arms to fall forward. "][/caption] Loosen your Shoulders In Uttanasana, interlace your hands behind your back and allow your arms to fall forward over your head. This should bring a deep stretch to loosen up your shoulders. Practice Balance Bakasana (bahk-AHS-anna) – Crow Pose Come to a squat on the floor with a few inches between your feet. Place your hands fully on the ground in front of you. Bend your elbows directly above your wrists. Slowly start to move your knees to rest on your elbows. Try to balance with your feet off the ground. It helps to find a point to look at in front of you!   [caption id="attachment_542" align="aligncenter" width="248" caption="Crow pose. Great balance practice!"][/caption] -Alexa

item.title: Freedom of the Hills Friday: Leave No Trace
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: Lovers of the outdoors face a major paradox every time they venture outside: the pristine nature that we value so much is impacted negatively with every step that we take. We want to spend weeks in the mountains, but every time we set down our tent and build a fire to keep warm, we create a footprint that, when multiplied by the millions of outdoorsmen, creates a serious impact. There are certain methods we've learned over the years in order to minimize our impact, such as clean climbing practices and making sure to  "Leave no Trace." By being acutely aware of our actions and our environment, we can keep our wilderness wild. The Leave No Trace Policy by Freedom of the Hills: 1) Plan ahead and prepare: Choose a realistic objective and check regulations. Limit party size. Eliminate excess packaging before you head out. 2) Travel and camp on durable surfaces: Stay on existing trails; spread out if off-trail. Camp at least 200 feet (60m) from water, trails, and people. Avoid clustering tents. Never level campsites, remove leaves or needles, or dig tranches. 3) Dispose of waste properly. Dig a cat hole; pack out toilet paper. Urinate on bare grounds or rocks. When camping on snow or ice, concentrate urine in a designated spot; cover yellow snow (and definitely don't eat it). On steep rock or ice faces, stream urine away from climbing route. 4) Leave what you find:  Avoid disturbing vegetation or rocks on climbing routes. 5) Minimize campfire impacts: Use only stoves; campfire rings and blackened trees may last for decades. 6) Respect wildlife: Never feed wildlife. Watch for nesting birds, especially raptors, on rock routes. 7) Be Considerate of other visitors: Camp away from other people; respect their privacy and avoid traveling through their space; speak quietly. Happy Weekend! Sarah

item.title: Dirty Running: Obstacle Mud Runs
item.dc:creator: SummerRepublic
item.content:encoded: With summer coming around, most of us can’t wait for the long days when we’ll be able to romp around and get active in the warm sun. This also means race season for lots of runners. But this year, in addition to running the same community 5K for the tenth time, try mixing it up with an obstacle mud run. This type of race is becoming increasingly popular and typically gives out free beer and a sweet swag bag. You'll be sure to have a great time with one of these popular series: [caption id="attachment_617" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Jumping over a fire obstacle in Spartan Race"][/caption] Spartan Race will have you running under barbed wire, climbing over walls, crossing rivers by jumping over a raft bridge, jumping through fire, carrying heavy things, running past Spartan warriors with foam barbells, and of course, sloshing through mud the whole way through. This large series of mud races tours with 3 race distances, called the Spartan Sprint (5K), Super Spartan (8+ miles), and the Spartan Beast (10-12 miles). A nice bonus with this series is that if you sign up, they’ll send you Workouts-of-the-Day and invite you to an online community of other “Spartans” to prep you for your race. Check out race locations online at spartanrace.com. Prices vary from $60 to $100 depending on how early you register. The Warrior Dash series is another very similar mud run, except that it only offers races about 5K distance. Warrior Dash tours nationally, so check warriordash.com and prices vary from $65 to $75 depending on how early you register. And if you want to take it up a notch, try upping the distance to 7 miles and running the whole course at night with Ultimate Mud Run-Night Ops. Sign up for the next event (tours nationally) at ultimatemudrun.com and it costs $129 and under, once again, depending on when you register. [caption id="attachment_621" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Plenty of opportunities to fall into muddy water"][/caption] Tough Mudder is the ultimate mud run that separates the athletes from the bad-asses. Tough Mudder is another touring series of 10-12mi obstacle course runs ready to kick your behind good and hard. With a grueling course designed by British Special Forces, have fun jumping into tanks of ice water, running through fire, climbing over everything imaginable, and crawling through mud the whole way. Oh, did I mention the last obstacle is a tunnel of hanging electric live wires? Some carrying up to 10,000 volts? All this pain is philanthropic though, because Tough Mudder supports the Wounded Warrior Project, which provides recovery programs to wounded United States veterans, and has already earned almost $3 million for the project. Sign up for this international series at toughmudder.com with registration costing between $95 and $200. I’m signed up for Warrior Dash and Spartan Sprint this summer. Think you have what it takes?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Generally all of these races will give you discounts or even free races if you volunteer for their street team (online marketing, promo codes, event booths) or if you volunteer the day of the race. For example, I'm on the street team for Spartan Races, and for every 8 hours I volunteer I get a free race. They also give me a promo code (punch in my code MASPARTA025 for 10% off your registration fee). There's some other cool bonuses as well. So generally you can find a way around paying full price because some of these races can be expensive.
Gonna be doing Tough Mudder in July! SO EXCITED

item.title: The North Face® Base Camp Duffel
item.dc:creator: Mad Dawg
item.content:encoded: Once upon a time, someone put some handles on some canvas and called it a duffle bag. Ever since that day, Boy Scouts, Army Rangers and Soccer Moms have been loading variations of this simple design with all their worldly possessions. And then trying to carry them. After decades of sore arms and awkward shuffles, the North Face Base Camp Duffle came along. Waterproof, durable, and easy to carry under any conditions. Pile it onto your roof rack, lash it to your sled, put it on your back, just don’t it them behind. One of the greatest challenges of any kind of travel, adventure or otherwise, is how to transport your necessary accessories to your destination. From taking your boots and helmet to Portillo to getting your rack to Indian Creek, these bags are a must have for the well (and perhaps overly) accessorized traveler.   The most notable feature of the Base Camp Duffels (other then the color selection) are their padded, fully adjustable straps that allow to you carry them on your back. While there is no frame, the bags are comfortable enough wear as you wander the streets of your destination city seeking shelter. Each long side is lined with gear loops to facilitate easy attachment to yaks, Land Rovers and all other means of transportation. The D-shaped zipper opening allows large objects to be placed inside with ease and a small, transparent window lets you label the bag as yours. Made of a waterproof laminate material, the Base Camp can left unattended in the elements while you pitch your tent or negotiate hostel fares. Watch any of today’s adventure/ski/climbing films and you are likely to see these bags being unloaded from the belly of a jet on some foreign tarmac. They come in every size, from the Mini, which contains my first aid kit, to the XL, which I can zip myself inside: •Avg Weight [Mini] 7 oz (200 g) •[Small] 2 lbs 12 oz (1250 g) •[Medium] 3 lbs 8 oz (1600 g) •[Large] 4 lbs (1820 g) •[XLarge] 4 lbs 15 oz (2240 g) •Volume [Mini] 250 in3 (4 liters) •[Small] 2560 in3 (42 liters) •[Medium] 4200 in3 (70 liters) •[Large] 5600 in3 (90 liters) •[XLarge] 9070 in3 (140 liters) •# Dimensions [Mini] 5 in. x 10 in. x 5 in. (12 cm x 24 cm x 12 cm) •# Dimensions [Small] 20 in. x 12 in. x 12 in. (51 cm x 31 cm x 31 cm) •# Dimensions [Medium] 24 in. x 15 in. x 15 in. (61 cm x 38 cm x 38 cm) •# Dimensions [Large] 28 in. x 16 in. x 16 in. (71 cm x 41 cm x 41 cm) •# Dimensions [XLarge] 32 in. x 19 in. x 19 in. (81 cm x 48 cm x 48 cm) A note on the quality of North Face luggage: The North Face backpack I use to lug my books around campus is the same North Face backpack I took with me on my first international trip. That was in 1995. There have been a few zipper replacements along the way, and a burn scar on the small pocket make it mine, but it is still standing, 17 years later. I have faith that the Base Camps will hold up just as well. The duffels range from $100-$175, depending on size and are available at most major outdoor retailers, such as REI and EMS. XOXO -Mad Dawg

item.title: Midnight Bike Ride of the Boston Marathon
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: Marathon Monday is a glorious tradition in Boston that falls on Patriots day every April. The majority of the city has a holiday from work and spends it cheering on the over 27,000 champions that choose to spend their day running/walking/crawling 26.2 miles through the treacherous Boston Marathon course. For those of us who chose to pass, there were many other ways to participate in the Bostonian spirit, without worrying about heatstroke for 4-5 hours.  You can volunteer either directly through the BAA (Boston Athletic Association) or through your school. Tufts, for example, is responsible for the water stations at miles 10, 11 and 22. Volunteering is an awesome experience, and you get a free jacket and hat for your time. I’ve done it two years now, and highly recommend it. You have to sign up early, however, as volunteer spots are very coveted. [caption id="attachment_640" align="alignright" width="196" caption="Piled into the commuter rail."][/caption] There is another Boston tradition, however, that I just found out about this year. It is the annual midnight bike ride of the marathon course the night before the actual race, when the barriers and mile markers are all set up. It is a free unofficial race, sponsored by no one, but organized by BostonSOS. This is how the event went down this year: Around 11 pm, we rolled into the Back Bay commuter rail station and crossed our fingers that the train hadn’t completely filled up at South Station. (The organizers asked that you show up at South Station at 10:15pm for the 11 pm train, since it takes forever to get 400 people and their bikes into a train.) By 11:30 we were all packed in, bikes piled on top of each other on top of seats, and the rest of the empty spaces filled with people in spandex talking about the ride last year and whether or not it was going to rain. [caption id="attachment_641" align="alignright" width="288" caption="Waiting for everyone to unload the train and get started, pre-rain."][/caption] Imagine 500 people and bikes in the middle of the street in the middle of the night, head and tail lights flashing, electrifying the normally quiet area of SouthBorough. There were many different types of people there, from pro-triathletes to people on mountain bikes with hipster sneakers on, but everyone was just pumped to be there. We were just about to start the 3 mile ride to the Marathon starting line when the skies opened up and it started to rain. And so we biked in the rain. There were multiple reasons why I was nervous for this ride: [caption id="attachment_642" align="alignright" width="300" caption="My poor seat was in pieces by the end of the race."][/caption] 1) I had never biked more than 15 miles before, and I was about to double that distance. 2) My seat was being held together by duct tape. 3) My “bike light” was my weak headlamp wrapped around my handlebars. 4) I was sure that someone was going to wipe out in front of me and I was going to die. Reasons I was nervous for other people: 1) Hubway bikes + tutus + beer. 2) The dude on roller skates. Worries aside, the rain cleared after about 20 minutes and I had one of the best bike rides of my life. It was truly awesome to bike through the normally heinous streets of Boston without worrying for my life.  It’s events like these that make city living a little less awful, especially when you know that some cool, athletic people are hiding out there too, ready to emerge when the awesomeness calls. [caption id="attachment_643" align="aligncenter" width="179" caption="Stoked at the finish line, cerca 3am."][/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: You would have loved it! Also, the guy on roller blades finished at the same time as us. That guy was bookin it. It's also interesting to note that it took us around 2 hours, which was close to the winning time for the running marathoners. Holy crap. They run as fast as I bike.
What another great adventure! I loved the description, the humor and the photos. Sounds like it's time to invest in some bike gear - headlight, tail light, bike seat.
Looks awesome, wish I could have been there!

Lessons Learned:
1.) Eat before a midnight bike ride, it's probably a good 5 or 6 hours since eating dinner. One Tufts kid almost passed out on his bike b/c he hadn't eaten since dinner. So he pulled over to a randomly open gas station and bought 5 power bars.
2.) Have someone in your crew bring a med kit. If you fall off your bike 15 miles from Boston while it's raining at 2am, it'll be a while before anyone comes to help you. We didn't bring a medical kit and luckily nothing bad happened but we did see three people who had fallen over, could have easily been one of us.
3.) Bring a small backpack for adventure rides like this. Your bike can typically carry your water and if you have a seat pouch you can carry your wallet, phone, keys but as with any adventure, what are you going to do if things go wrong and no one is there to help you? A med kit, rain jacket, and food would have been good items to bring and a small backpack would have been perfect for this.
4.) Beware train tracks. 2/3 of the people we saw on the side of the road who had fallen where there because of slippery train tracks.
5.) Have some snacks at your apt/dorm waiting for you when you get back with the munchies at 3am.
6.) Wear a costume and strap a battery-powered radio to your handlebars.
Had a blast at the race, it's already in my calendar for next year.

Awesome recap! I'm so glad you came and enjoyed the ride, even with the surprise rain..There were two dudes on roller blades, and I got to talk to them for a bit during the flash downpour before I settled on hanging out with the giant unicycle girl.
And for the record, our semi-official count was around 600 bikes and people on the train, and around 700 after we joined up with the people waiting at Southborough statiion. See you next year for our 5th Annual midnight marathon ride!
-Greg Hum Founder, Midnight Marathon Bike Ride (now teamed up with Societies of Spontaneity)

item.title: Freedom of the Hills Friday: Climbing Communication
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: Poor communication is one of the most dangerous mistakes you can make while out on a rock climb. Whether you're sport climbing or doing a long multi-pitch, clear and concise communication is essential to getting you and your partners up and down safely. Here are a few basic commands that you will hear anywhere from a climbing gym to a gnarly alpine route. Climber refers to any climber on top rope or on lead. Leader refers to commands specific to lead climbers and their belayers. Climber: "On belay?" (Do you have me on belay?) [caption id="attachment_667" align="alignright" width="300" caption="On Belay!"][/caption] Belayer: "Belay On." (I'm belaying you.) Climber: "Climbing." (I'm moving up and on the rock so pay attention.) Belayer: "Climb or Climb On." (The belayer acknowledging that they're paying attention.) Climber: "Slack." (Give me some slack and leave it out until I call "Climbing.") Climber: "That's me." (All slack is pulled in; don't pull any more or I'll fall off.) Climber: "Watch me." (I anticipate a fall or difficult move.) Climber: "Falling" or what I normally say "AHHHH." (Assume braking position and brace for a pull on the rope.) Leader: "Take!" (I expect to weight the rope or fall; take up slack and apply braking force.) [caption id="attachment_668" align="alignright" width="300" caption="These commands are key if your partner is out of sight."][/caption] Leader: "How much rope?" (What length of rope remains?) Belayer: "Feet...four...zero." (40 Feet remains.) Leader: "Off Belay." (I'm secure; take belay apart and prepare to follow the pitch.) Follower: "Belay off." (After taking apart the belay. Pull in slack and remaining coils when you're ready.) Anyone: "ROCK! ICE!" (Loudly repeat until falling object stops. Do not look up.) Anyone: "Rope!" (Rappel rope is about to be thrown down; look out and take cover.) Climber: "On rappel!" (I'm about to rappel.)   Climb on!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: so, this is sort of like tweeting?

Haha. In terms of quick, clear, and direct communication, yes. In terms of safety and importance, no.
It's more just a universal language that can be used between all climbers.

item.title: Upping the Mileage
item.dc:creator: SummerRepublic
item.content:encoded: Time to put in some major mileage. Since coming to Tufts, I’ve become more intensive with my running because I’ve found it’s the perfect sport for a busy college student. I can chose when I run, how far, and how to train for a major event. It’s come to mean much more to me than just a way to stay in shape. When I run, it’s like running away from and running towards something all at the same time. I literally run away from any stress I have on campus, but at the same time I’m running towards a larger goal of seeing the limits of where my body can take me.  Then, when I race and finish well, it gives me more confidence to keep reaching further. The other day I ran an 11.11-mile long run. And felt great about it. I ran at a good pace and could have kept going, but it was getting dark and I did not want to be running in the city at night. The fact that I could go that far made me so proud about what my body could do. But I still want more. So I have decided to run a half-marathon. To achieve this goal, I will follow a training schedule from CoolRunning.com, and will follow the intermediate plan. This website has a lot of great training plans for the most popular distances, from a Couch-to-5K plan to a marathon plan. I invite you to join me in training for a half! Since starting the plan a couple weeks ago, it puts me at a race date around July. I’m pretty sure I’m going to do the ShipYard Old Port Half Marathon in Portland, Maine on July 22nd. I want to run it under 2 hours, which I'm sure for me is doable, considering I ran the 11.11 miles in a little under an hour and a half. Follow me as I’ll be posting training updates as I get to my goal!  Web Links: Cool Running Training Programs ShipYard Old Port Half-Marathon, Portland, Maine

item.title: Tips for Running in Hot Summer Weather
item.dc:creator: Mad Dawg
item.content:encoded: This past April, the 116th Boston Marathon was run in record breaking temperatures that topped out at 87 degrees. Over the course of the day, approximately 2100 participants were treated by the volunteer medical staff; an increase of almost 800 over last year.  One patient arrived at a hospital with a body temperature of 108-degrees. With the arrival of summer on the horizon, and many of us eager to take advantage of the warm weather, it is important to understand the toll high temperatures can take on your body, and how to keep yourself cool and safe on your adventures. Understanding how your body cools itself Your body loses heat four ways: Conduction-heat lost from direct contact with something cooler then you Radiation- heat lost directly from skins surface Convection- heat lost through movement of air around your body Evaporation-vaporization of sweat On a hot day, Evaporation is the only method that effectively cools you. Unfortunately, the actual production of sweat does nothing, it has to be able to evaporate as well. In hot, dry climates, like my native New Mexico, this is extremely effective. In humid conditions, like Boston, evaporation becomes less and less effective. When your body cannot effectively release heat, your internal temperature begins to rise and bad things, such as heat exhaustion and heat stroke, start to happen. Many people use these terms interchangeably, but they are very different conditions, and knowing the difference can save a life. Symptoms of Heat Exhaustion: -Headache -Dizziness -Nausea -Rapid breathing -Exhaustion -Skin feels cool, has goose bumps -Chills Treatment of Heat Exhaustion: -Move victim into the shade -Oral rehydration with a slightly salty drink -It takes an hour to get a liter back into circulation, so the recovery process will be slow -Not physiologically damaging-but can lead to heat stroke if left untreated Heat Stroke: -Sudden and very noticeable alteration in mental function: disorientation, irritability, combativeness, bizarre delusions, and incoherent speech -Skin is hot, red, wet -Elevated vitals Treatment of Heat Stroke: -Quick cooling-cold water, ice applied to circulation centers -If this cannot be accomplished where you are, then evacuation -Physiologically damaging-can be deadly The easiest way to avoid becoming a victim is to know when to stay inside. NOAA has a Heat Index table that indicates how hot it is and how hot it actually feels when relative humidity is factored with actual air temperature, as well as the likelihood of acquiring a heat disorder with prolonged exposure. Whether you are a seasoned warm-weather runner, or a newbie, here are some tips to keep you safe while you are out there getting after it (these also apply to similar activities such as hiking and biking). Pre-Run The best thing you can do for yourself is to be adequately hydrated before you start. If you are running in the morning, this means making sure you drink a lot of water the evening before, especially if you have been consuming alcohol. And forgo your morning coffee, or at least postpone it until after your run. This is often out of your control, but if you are feeling sick, think twice about facing the heat. Being sick can affect your ability to thermoregulate effectively, which is bad-news-bears when efficient cooling is essential. If you are a cool weather critter, and this whole heat thing seems a little weird, give your body time to adjust, just like you would acclimate if you went up in elevation. This can take up to 2-3 weeks, so be patient. Gear: So you can’t control the weather, but just like with the cold and the wet, you can dress for the occasion. Head Soak a light-colored, brimmed hat in water and put in the fridge. Put it on just before you head out the door. Invest in some sports sunglasses that stay put when you run and don’t fog up when you sweat. Oakley Half-Jackets are sexy (And Lance wears them), but I have had great success with $8 gas station wrap-arounds. Wear a hat. Not a visor. Athletes are one of the groups most at risk for developing skin cancer. Parts, receding hairlines and championship season buzz cuts are just as vulnerable to burns as the bridge of your nose. Get one that is easily adjustable, and of a wicking fabric and works with your bun/ponytail/braid configuration of choice. Neck Invest in Kafka Kool Tie, a cotton bandana filled with polymer crystals that soak up and then slowly release water to create a prolonged evaporative cooling effect. If you don’t have the $10, a regular bandana can be soaked in water and used in the same manner. This won’t last as long, but is a good trick, especially when hiking along a stream, where it can we re-wetted frequently. Long sleeves may seem counter intuitive in the heat, but a light weight long-sleeved wicking shirt is essential for running in hot weather. The light color will reflect some of the heat from the sun, and the wicking fabric will keep your skin temperature lower for longer. When running for longer than an hour, especially on your own, away from civilization, you need to bring water. You DO NOT need a Fuel Belt, a CamelBack, or special hand-held bottle. A plastic water bottle or any bottle that fits in your hand (sorry, no sticker-covered Nalgenes, these are unbelievably hard to run with) placed inside of a tube sock will get the job done. The sock will absorb the sweat from your hand and the condensation form the water bottle. I, personally, find that carrying water in my hand is way less annoying then carrying on my back or around my waist, but you will have to experiment to find out what is the most comfortable for you. The one exception to this is if I am going for longer then two hours away from any form of support. Then I grab a hydration pack. [caption id="attachment_792" align="alignright" width="174" caption="Tufts students deal with the heat by not wearing pants."][/caption] The Run Now that you have dressed for the occasion, tailor the occasion to the conditions. Making plans according to the weather is just as important in the heat as the cold. Avoid the heat and run early or late. Look at the forecast for the next day and plan to be finishing your run before the heat becomes intolerable. In places like Phoenix or Miami, it is not uncommon for people to run as early as 3:30 in the morning to avoid the heat. While this is extreme, changing when you exercise will keep you cooler then anything else. Plan your run on an out and back course so you can leave yourself a water cache on the way out. This was you don’t have to carry your water the whole way and can go for longer without having to carry a pack. Slow down and lower your expectations. You cannot perform as well in 90 degree heat as you can in 60 degree heat. Period. End of story. Be smart and back off, especially if you feel sick or dizzy. If you are lucky enough to be located near a pool, pond, lake or ocean, then run near, to or from, a body of water. A quick dip, mid or post run, will help regulate your body temperature, and feel amazing. While you should always take a phone with you, anytime you expect situations to be extreme, you should absolutely take one with you. I understand wanting to escape from technology, but I have never been more grateful for it then the time I had to call my father to come get me when I started to black out during a run. It doesn’t have to be on, but it does need to be with you incase things go wrong. Post-Run Congratulations, you have survived! Now, take care of yourself so you can get out there again tomorrow. Cool off as soon as you can. Jump into a pool/lake/ocean, spray yourself down with the hose or put some cold packs on your neck, under your armpits and…down there. These are your bodies circulation centers, and a change in temperature hear will have the most noticeable effect on overall body temperature. Hydrate, Hydrate, Hydrate. Your body can lose up to 2 ½ liters of water per hour during prolonged exercise, but it can only reabsorb about 1 liter per hour, which means that you need to continue rehydrating for a long time after you finish your run. Make sure you include a slightly salty liquid, such as watered down Gatorade or equivalent sports drink.

item.title: Freedom of the Hills Friday: First-Aid Kit
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded:
If there is one thing that you should always bring with you on an adventure, it should be your first-aid kit. First aid kits can be as basic as the bandaids and neosporin you have in you house, to a full Wilderness First Responder kit. However, neither of these are appropriate for you, the weekend adventurer.  You can easily buy a First-Aid kit from an outdoor store like Eastern Mountain Sports for $15-$60. It's good to have a bag or container that screams FIRST AID in case someone needs to find it for you! I bought a basic first aid kit from EMS and then supplemented it with a few additional neccesities.  Here is the list of things that should be in your First Aid Kit according to Freedom of the Hills. I've put a * next to what I have in mine:
  • *Adhesive bandages
  • *Butterfly bandages/Steristrips
  • *Sterile gauze pads
  • Carlisle bandage/sanitary napkin
  • * Non-adherent dressing
  • Self-adhering roller bandages
  • SAM splint (malleable). I don't have one of these although I should. If worst came to worst, I would splint a bone with my ace bandage and some sticks, or use a sleeping pad if it were a leg. I highly reccomend taking a Wilderness First Aid course to practice these skills.
  • *Athletic Tape
  • *Triangular bandages
  • *Moleskin/Molefoam
  • Tincture of Benzoin
  • *Providone-iodine swabs
  • *Alcohol/Soap pads
  • Thermometer
  • Super packets
  • *Asprin/acetaminophen
  • Anaphylaxis kit (Epi Pen)
  • Antihistamin
  • *Elastic bandage (like an ACE bandage)
  • *Latex or nitrile gloves
  • Safety Pins
  • Tweezers
  • *Plastic bag for contaminated items
  • *Disposable breathing barrier
  • *Pen, Paper, accident report form.
In addition to what I said I have on this list, I also have a strong inhaler in my kit since I used to have sports induced asthma and I've found it useful for other people I've been hiking with as well. This list is pretty barebones, and many people bring much much more with them. Better to be safe than sorry! If you're going out on an adventure this weekend and don't have time to put one of these together, at least bring an Ace Bandage, some sports tape, and some latex gloves. They will help you get you out of some nasty situations.

item.title: LL Bean Gore-Tex Mountain Treads Hiking Boots
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded:
When it comes down to essential pieces of gear, I would argue that there is no piece more fundamental than your hiking boots. Whether you’re hiking, climbing, rafting, or kayaking, you need your feet to get you there. A sturdy, comfortable, and waterproof pair of boots can make or break a trip; there’s nothing like a blister or wet feet to turn a good weekend bad. [caption id="attachment_760" align="aligncenter" width="542" caption="And let me tell you, they really do mean it."][/caption]

Growing up, my parents had bought me boots for our annual summer trips, but my mother was always of the opinion that I would “grow into” my boots. Needless to say I never quite enjoyed wearing them. They were either too big, too small, or too heavy. I didn’t even have a pair that fit when I came to college.

For my first hiking trip with the Tufts Mountain Club as a freshman, I borrowed a pair from a friend of mine. We happened to be the same size, and as luck would have it, they fit me perfectly. It was life changing. I knew right then I had to have a pair of my own. I started talking to other folks in the club, as well as friends and family, and soon learned about the glorious lifetime guarantee of LL Bean. My friend’s dad had owned the same pair of hiking boots for 40 years. Every time they got old or fell apart, LL Bean replaced them, no questions asked. Now that’s my kind of company. [caption id="attachment_761" align="alignright" width="295" caption="They come in two different color schemes. I've had both!"][/caption] I drove up to Maine, to LL Bean’s flagship store, and scored myself an amazing pair of boots 30% off. Let me please introduce you to LL Bean’s Women’s Gore-Tex Mountain Treads, Mid-Cut. The average college student might gag at the price ($150) and even I was a little hesitant to pay $100 for them, but they have more than paid for themselves. Not only am I on my 3rd pair of these babies (the first ones I dropped in a fire and burned the sole off, the second one squished my toes), but I wear them more than any other shoe. The high ankle of the boot is not only crucial for people with weak ankles like myself, and they are waterproof all the way up the laces making it a breeze to cross rivers. I also wear them in the winter around campus as my snow/slush boots. The boots are sturdy and hold my foot well in place, and have awesome traction. They are also great for icier conditions, simply by putting on a pair of micro-spikes. Going back to the price, even if I had paid $150, since I’m on pair 3, that’s only $50 per pair, and I’m sure that I will get at least a few more replacements out of them. Hands-down the best deal for a solid pair of boots. -SL ps: I have 3 male friends who have the Men's version of these boots. They are just a good and my friend's love them as much as I do.

item.title: Hiking the Kalalau Trail on Kauai Hawaii
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded: Every one of us has a list. You know, that list you keep in the back of your head, or scribble down in a notebook somewhere that keeps track of all of the trips that you would like to do in your life. Whether it’s hiking the Appalachian Trail or Paragliding across Europe, we all have those dream trips that we would do if someone gave us the time, money, and perfect opportunity. As a student, I rarely have any of these luxuries. But this summer, for the first time in my life, I finally got to cross a trip off of my list. The 11 mile hike along the Na Pali coast on the island of Kauai in Hawaii is the only land access to the [caption id="attachment_776" align="alignright" width="293" caption="Hanging out on the beach at Kalalau."][/caption] gorgeous and powerful valley and beach of Kalalau. The hiking is rather difficult, although totally do-able in one day in order to reach the beach. Although Mike and I consider ourselves very fit and athletic, the trail goes up and down through countless valleys, and with full packs on, it makes for long day. The hike as well as the destination are breathtaking, and it is undeniably the most beautiful and incredible trip I’ve ever done. In what other place will you be rewarded with a million dollar view after every uphill section (and there were dozens). Once you arrive at Kalalau, you have your pick of campsites right along the beach, and you’re biggest decision is how close to the waterfall shower and naked hippies do you want to be? You heard me, naked hippies. Why do you think this trip was on my list? Legend has it that this isolated valley used to be home to dozens of hippies who lived off the land and lived in a happy, naked paradise. My dad used to tell me that the farther into the hike you got, the less clothing people wore. He wasn’t exactly wrong. Not much has changed, although people are significantly more dressed than I assume they were in the 60’s and 70’s, but it is still common place to remove all clothing when in contact with any body of water (ocean, stream, or otherwise). The trip isn’t in itself that strenuous or out of the reach of any relatively fit person. Heck, you don’t even need that much gear (or clothing), but rather it’s the fact that you can only do this hike in the summer, and the logistics of getting to the trail head in the first place the make this trip so elusive. First you have to get yourself to Honolulu. I recommend spending a day or two there since no matter where you’re coming from you’re in for a long flight, and you’ll probably need a day or two to adjust to your jet-lag. Hawaii has a good amount of hostels and a rather thorough bus system (beware, the buses run on Hawaiian Time so bring a book). [caption id="attachment_778" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Hanging out at the airport, cerca 5 am."][/caption] Next comes the fun part. If you are on a budget of time and money, like we were, you’re going to want to get on the trail as soon as possible. We caught the earliest flight out of Honolulu that you can on Hawaiian Air. It cost us about $230 roundtrip to get to Kauai and back to Honolulu.  We arrived in Lihue, Kauai at about 6:10 am and managed to just miss the airport shuttle that would take us to the bus stop. However,  an $8 cab got us to our bus stop in time where we caught a local bus (one of three on the island) all the way to Hanalei. It cost us $2 each, and hour of bus time, and plenty of dirty looks with our big packs and haole selves (haole=white person). Once you get to Hanalei, you have a couple of options. 1) Hitch hike the 12 miles to the trailhead (it’s literally at the end of the road, you can’t miss it). This is probably your best option. People are so nice there and trust me, weirder people than you have tried to get to Kalalau. 2) Call ahead of time for a taxi (it’s a slow drive, so this might be costly) 3) Convince the local tour guides to hook you up with a ride We managed to make a few calls ahead of time and happened to have a family friend in Kauai who kindly drove us to and picked us up from the trailhead (Emma, if you’re reading this, Mahalo Nui Loa!) [caption id="attachment_779" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Our campsite."][/caption] Once I finally figured out the logistics of getting to and from the hike, we focused on our packing list. We decided to take 5 days to do the trip, which I would recommend as an absolute minimum. Everyone who only spent one or two nights there regretted it. I will list some of the crucial things we needed as well as some things to remember: 1) A water filter. Hawaii has leptospirosis. ‘Nough said. 2) A shelter with a bug net/rain fly. There are lots of mosquitoes and it will consistently shower almost every day. Hammocks were very popular there. 3) A stove. If you choose to do this, you will have to buy fuel at one of the local kayak shops in Hanalei since you can’t bring fuel on a plane. 4) Sunscreen, bug repellant (crucial), biodegradable soap. Remember <3oz for a plane so either buy them in Hanalei, or check a small bag ($17 on Hawaiian Air). There is a huge Aloe plant by the composting toilets so if you get a burn, that will help a lot. 5) Basic trail food is good but I highly suggest, if you’re up for carrying the weight, bringing some booze. We carried in 3 liters of wine and some rum. Heavy as crap but totally worth it. We made friends real fast and never went hungry. Can you say Kalalau Pizza? Plus, our packs were super light on the way out! 6) Something to sleep on. I don’t say sleeping bag here because you don’t really need one. Mike had a sleeping bag liner and I put a towel over my sleeping pad and used my nylon hammock as a sheet when I wanted it. We were more than comfortable. [caption id="attachment_784" align="alignright" width="240" caption="Hanakapi'ai Fall and swimming pool"][/caption] Remember, you don’t really need a lot. A light fleece might be nice, but the temperature stays pretty stable during the summer. I also recommend a book or playing cards if you plan on staying for more than 3 or 4 nights.  Michael and I had 40L and 50L packs respectively, which was plenty of room. We saw people hiking with 80L packs and they looked miserable A few last tips: There is a campsite at Hanakoa which is 5 miles from Kalalau. I highly recommend doing what we did, which is hiking the extra 4 miles into Hanakapi’ai falls, and then if you run out of daylight or are tired later, you can easily camp at Hanakoa. If you are planning on doing this trip and have any more questions, please don’t hesitate to email me questions at sarah@collegeoutside.com  More resources: Book your permit 6 months ahead of time here: http://www.hawaiistateparks.org/camping/permit_napali.cfm Kauai Bus Schedules: http://www.kauai.gov/Government/Departments/TransportationAgency/BusSchedules/tabid/208/Default.aspx Waikiki Hostel: http://www.waikikibeachsidehostel.com/ Where you can buy fuel in Hanalei: https://www.kayakkauai.com/index2.php
