item.title: Barefoot Running: A Shoeless Investigation
item.dc:creator: collegeoutside
item.content:encoded:
One of the fitness trends that I've been keeping an eye on for a few years has been the rise of barefoot runners. Unless you've been under a rock for the past couple of years, you're probably familiar with Christopher McDougall, or at least his recent best seller Born to Run. After years of running and multiple injuries later, he had doctors tell him that he would need to replace his knees and hips. It was then that he discovered the Tarahumara Indians in the Copper Canyon of Mexico. They were a people that could run hundreds of miles at a time in thin rubber sandals without ever getting hurt. What he learned from them was that the debate on barefoot running is not necessarily about the footwear, but about how you run. [caption id="attachment_798" align="alignright" width="350" caption="There are all different styles of minimalist or barefoot running shoes out these days."][/caption] As someone who suffers from a chronic sprain in my left ankle and wicked tight hips, I was an easy sell. I untied my Asics and took off for a jog. I quit a mile later, not wanting to hurt myself, which was probably the right choice as I was sore for days. The tops of my feet as well as the lower area of my calves ached and made me realize that these were areas of my body I didn't normally use when I run.
Intrigued, but not yet convinced, I set out to learn more by doing some investigating around campus and, like any good college student, by watching a lot of YouTube videos.
Barefoot running has gathered a huge following in the past few years, with multiple shoe companies like Nike and Vibrams picking up on the trend. Die-hard fans claim that running without shoes is not only more natural, but over all beneficial to the human body. Even those who still prefer the ol’ sneaker see the benefits of running barefoot as a training tool to make you a more conscious runner. “[Running barefoot] is a great regulator,” McDougall said. “You can’t over pronate [rotating your feet inward], you can’t over train, you can’t over stride. If you’re in the middle of a run and your feet start to hurt, you’re done for the day.” With the hundreds of models of running shoes available today, it seems almost ludicrous to ignore all of the biomechanical engineering that goes into making a shoe that is designed to make you run faster. But according to the barefoot-enthusiasts, these highly engineered shoes are where the problem started. Think of your current pair of running shoes. They probably have nice think rubber soles to absorb the shock of the ground and nice arch support. These features, however, have lead us to change our natural stride. The built in arch for example makes the muscles in the arch of your foot lazy and may in turn cause you more problems in the long run. Instead of striking with the heel, barefoot runners land on the forefront of their foot and then bring the heel down. This in fact decreases the impact to the body and is over all more efficient. (Have you ever been called a heel-striker? I have. I need new friends.) [caption id="attachment_797" align="alignright" width="232" caption="You'd be stoked too if you ran Ragnar in Vibrams."][/caption] When he’s not running barefoot, Simon, a Tufts student, and a few of his friends wear these five-finger shoes during the day. You may have started to see more and more students around campus replacing their converses with Vibrams. “As a runner, I had chronic shin splints all through high school,” said Simon. His friend, Joshua Elliott, used to have tendinitis and arch pain as well. Similar to McDougall, their injuries have disappeared every since they switched to Vibrams. “I swear by these things,” said Elliott. “I would prefer to be barefoot but in many public places you are required to wear shoes so by wearing Vibrams, it’s like I’ve found a loophole.” This back to barefoot approach, however, may not be for everyone. Patricia Cordeiro, a sports therapist at Tufts walks to work everyday in a pair of Vibrams. “From a professional standpoint I don't think that everyone can run in them,” said Cordeiro. “There are certain people (like myself) who have certain biomechanical issues who require an orthotic or motion control shoe for running.” Cordeiro, like many others, see barefoot running as a good training and strengthening tool. “I noticed an increase in lower leg strength especially in my feet and toes I never had before,” she said. “The first time I wore them for a 15 min. walk home from the T and my legs were sore the next day...even though I had been biking 50-60 miles, running 5-15 miles and swimming a ton already. I think all athletes would benefit from barefoot training each day in order to strengthen the smaller muscles in their feet and it might decrease the number of people we see with foot, lower leg and knee pain.” I don't know which group, heel or non-heel strikers, is right, although I do know that I've started to get in a barefoot run every now and then, and that I haven't sprained my ankle in a while. Nonetheless, I'm not a total convert, vanity mostly, so I think I'll stick to my Asics for now.

item.title: 5 Running Gear Essentials
item.dc:creator: SummerRepublic
item.content:encoded: As a student paying an expensive private college tuition, I keep a strict budget. I’ve learned to live and entertain myself on the dime, and that’s one of the reasons I find running the perfect sport. Just spend about a $100 on a pair of shoes, and you’re good to go. No special costly gear needed. But in all my training, through hours and hours, miles and miles, there are certain things that are just really nice to have, especially over long distances. These are a few pieces of gear that I’ve  learned help out, even more so in hot weather. A roller: It’s like a mini-massage after every run. Great for getting out knots and easing sore muscles, which is especially nice when you are logging serious milage daily. I even find them nice before a run to refresh muscles. iPod armband: Up until the middle of my half marathon, I was determined not to buy an armband. I only had a case and would only ever hold my iPod or tuck it in my clothes. So this is what I did for my half. Then at mile 8 my music stopped playing because it got wet (it had suffered some Gatorade splashes, water splashes, cool-down water mists, and general sweat). I finally dried it and got it to work again, but those few minutes of mild panic was when I decided yeah, an armband is probably a good investment. I encourage you not to make the same mistake I did. Anti-chafe balm: This prevents any irritation due to the combination of sweat, heat and repeated rubbing during a long race. This is good for underarms, chest, and legs. A safety light/reflective belt: To beat the heat, I, like others, tend to run after dark. Accordingly, it’s important to be very visible, even if your route keeps you on sidewalks. You will eventually encounter some unobservant driver who stops in the middle of a crosswalk or blindly pulls out of their driveway. A bright flashing light will make sure they see you. A great pair of shoes, fitted and matched just for you: I've heard many new runners try to find a bargain online or buy the fanciest shoes without even trying them on, and then end up unsatisfied with their shoes. I suggest you go to your local running specialty store, get your stride and gait analyzed, and get the pair of shoes perfectly suited to you. Don’t shop online, don’t go to a general athletics store, just enjoy the advice of a store staffed by experienced knowledgeable runners. If they don’t recommend the cheapest pair or even the fanciest pair, trust them, test them out in store, and buy a pair of shoes you know you’ll love for hundreds of miles. What pieces of gear will you not leave on your run without?

item.title: Strategy on Buying Your Own Climbing Gear
item.dc:creator: k.hitchner09
item.content:encoded: So you’re brand new to all this outdoors stuff - climbing, hiking, biking, etc. - and all the gear that goes along with it. It’s ok, I was just there too, and I’m here to help!  Today's focus is climbing gear, though there are posts about hiking and cycling to come.  Between sizing, safety, pricing, and, of course, coolness, there is a lot to think about with these sports.  Here are a few of my tips! This may seem odd, but Tip #1 is : Don’t buy the gear! Well, let me be more specific - don’t buy it yet.  Gear is expensive.  It’s important to be sure that you are going to stick with the sport in order for your investment to pay off.  Paying $60 (and thats on the low end!) for a harness you only use twice isn’t worth it on a college student’s budget.  Second, borrowing friends’ gear will give you a great product testing period.  You can see what you do and don’t like before putting down the money yourself.  With these ideas in mind, I suggest waiting until your friends are absolutely sick of you borrowing their gear or until you're going so often that your adventure time is being limited by your access to the gear.  Those are both pretty good indicators that it's time to make the investment. So now you think you’re ready to buy your own gear.  Here is Tip #2: Be strategic about the order in which you buy things. [caption id="attachment_856" align="alignright" width="305"] You can use your biking helmet for climbing, and your climbing helmet for biking! Note: NOT recommended.[/caption] For climbing this means you should get shoes, a harness, and an ATC first.  Helmet and chalk bag can come second. If you are really stretching it, I would say shoes are the first thing to buy.  They're the most difficult to borrow, given differences in sizes, whereas harnesses are adjustable.  As for helmets, you may look silly for a few outings, but you can easily use a bike or ski helmet in lieu of a climbing helmet.  If you are climbing in the gym, helmets won’t even be necessary. Tip # 3: Use discount/flash sale gear sites. A list of these can be found here.  If you're willing to be a little patient, you can find almost any piece of gear you want on sale.  Especially if you’re looking in the off-season. There you have it.  The top three things I recommend doing before you go make your first gear purchase.  Happy climbing!
